story:
During the past few years I have been working with a research team, called the Model G and Vortical Motion Group, that currently has 7 active members volunteering their time to computer simulate a novel reaction-diffusion system, one that could bring about a quantum jump in our understanding of the physical world. Our group is sponsored by the Starburst Foundation, a non-profit scientific research institute conducting leading edge transdisciplinary research in the fields of physics, astronomy, geology, palaeontology, and systems theory. Starburst is supported entirely by charitable donations. Information about it can be found at starburstfound.org .
- Brendan Darrer, a physicist with a Ph.D. from University College London from 2017. 

 

Over the past year, our group has been attempting to progress this work by including vortical motion/rotation into the reaction-diffusion equations in the hope of modelling quantum particle spin. SQK theorizes that an ether vortex would develop in the particle's core and that this produces what physicists refer to as particle spin magnetic moment. By achieving this we would make Model G (i.e. SQK) more physically realistic, i.e. include the known subatomic property of spin, thus upgrading it to describe science and technologies on the quantum and subquantum levels. At present, physics has no official conceptual model of what spin is, it just assumes it as a property of subatomic particles. SQK goes further to explain the details of how spin forms. Currently we are also working to simulate Model G in two and three dimensions. We hope this will eventually allow us to simulate solitons that demonstrate the ability to elastically scatter from other solitons in a way similar to what takes place in the physical world on the subatomic level.

links to the reading resources mentioned in the above video:

Our early simulation work involved use of a c++ code using exponential time differencing to solve the PDEs of Model G. It is described in the following journal paper:

Pulver, M. & LaViolette, P. A., “Stationary Dissipative Solitons of Model G.” International Journal of General Systems, Vol. 42, No. 5, July 2013, 519–541.

https://starburstfound.org/downloads/physics/model_g.pdf

The stack exchange page accessible at the following link summarizes some of what we have been doing:

https://tinyurl.com/yc73uz5l

SQK (Model G) is based on the Brusselator reaction system, as mentioned in the video. The Brusselator had been previously developed by mathematicians at the Brussels School under the direction of Nobel Laureate Ilya Prigogine.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brusselator

The advantages of Model G in accounting for physical phenomena ranging from the microphysical to the astronomical and cosmological levels are presented in the e-book: "Subquantum Kinetics" by Paul LaViolette Ph.D. which may be purchased at this location:

https://etheric.com/subquantum-kinetics-4th-edition/

Book reviews may be found here:

https://etheric.com/LaVioletteBooks/SQK-review.html

Papers on subquantum kinetics are also available for free download at the Starburst Foundation website at:

https://starburstfound.org/paper-archive/

In addition, you may be interested to try your hand at the Model G simulator available on the Starburst Foundation website at:

https://starburstfound.org/model-g-transmuting-ether-simulator

Here is a link to our recent paper on Model G (July 2020)

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/342393172_EXPLANATION_OF_MODEL_G_IN_SUBQUANTUM_KINETICS

 

Technological Applications of Subquantum Kinetics:

Utilizing the open system paradigm Subquantum Kinetics (SQK) (or Model G) allows us to analyze many propulsion and over-unity energy technologies that cannot be explained by conventional physics. The electro-gravitic technologies that it can describe are as follows. Townsend Brown's electrogravitic thruster; the Podkletnov gravity impulse beam, and the Searl disc. Also T. T. Brown’s asymmetrical capacitor and the Nassikas superconducting thruster. SQK conceives the electric field potential (ether concentration gradient) and magnetic field (ether vortex currents) as being seated in the ether as opposed to being attached to the field sources that generate them. As a result, in the case of Brown’s asymmetrical thrusters and the Nassikas thruster, these fields can exert unbalanced forces on these novel machines, enabling propulsion without action of outside forces, in violation of Newton’s third law. Additionally, the Nassikas thruster violates the 1st law of thermodynamics. SQK could describe technologies that can tap into the ether and create energy that is clean and very cheap! It therefore provides us with a new paradigm of physics and the universe, one where over-unity energy generation and violation of current physics laws becomes possible.

 

A technical note on Model G spin:

“Etherons continually diffuse radially inward and outward between the particle’s core and its inner Turing wave shell. Inward and outward radial fluxes are also present between each of its successive shells. For example, in the nucleon, X-ons in the inner high-X shell would diffuse inward to the particle’s central low-X core as well as outward to the adjacent second shell which maintains a low-X concentration (see figure 16 below). Also Y-ons in the high-Y core would diffuse outward to the inner low-Y shell, and this inner low-Y shell would also receive an inward directed Y-on flux from the adjacent second shell which would maintain a high-Y concentration. The diffusive flux vector for these radial fluxes would be highest between the core and its adjacent inner shell, and it is here where vortical movement of the diffusive fluxes would be most likely to first develop. Vortical etheric convection (see 2nd figure below) would be prone to occur since it would enhance the rate of inward transport into the core. Once established in the core region, this vortical movement would spread outward through the particle’s Turing wave pattern.

“Just as a moving charge would generate curl components in its virtual electric force field, so too, through its vortical diffusive flux, a subatomic particle would generate curl components that would cause its surrounding electric potential Turing wave pattern to develop magnetic effects, even when the particle was not in motion relative to its ether ambient. This may be what causes a subatomic particle to have the property of spin. This property was first discovered in 1922 in an experiment carried out by Stern and Gerlach. They found that when a beam of atoms was made to pass through a non-uniform magnetic field, the atoms deflected towards either the north or south magnetic polar axis direction depending on the direction of their particle’s spin axis relative to this externally imposed field. Future investigation should determine whether Model G particles with vortical diffusive movement in their Turing wave pattern could interact with the equivalent of an inhomogeneous magnetic field in such a way that a Stern-Gerlach type of deflection phenomenon would occur.” [1]

“Viewed in three-dimensions, the fluxes between the core of a subatomic particle and its adjacent shell might look as shown in the above Figure, where the two sets of whorls would represent the inward flux of one specie, say X, and the outward flux of its complement specie Y. Interestingly, this diagram, which was intended to represent “units of matter more fundamental than the atom,” was intuited by Charles Leadbeater and Annie Besant in 1895, about a decade before the discovery of subatomic particles.” [1]

References

[1] LaViolette, P.A., 2012. Subquantum Kinetics: A Systems Approach to Physics and Astronomy. 4th ebook ed. Niskayuna, NY: Starlane Publications.

 

So basically, contributors who fund us, will be helping our group to upgrade Subquantum kinetics (Model G), and make it a more powerful theory, one that will aid scientists to understand the physical universe in a new way, and the beneficial technologies that can come from it.

We are aiming to raise $12,000.00 (USD) for the Starburst Foundation in the US. We will spend it on buying cloud computing time, so that we can have enough computer power to run the simulations required, to test out the spin properties of Model G. Also we will need to cover publication expenses to journals.

If we do not entirely reach our goal, the funds we raise will go into Starburst Foundation, and be used to support its research projects.

Our project is valuable to our contributors and to humanity, because it will help progress a ground breaking new science that could bring about many benefits. Such as, new nature friendly technologies, new scientific discoveries, and a theoretical framework to describe it accurately and logically.

 

Dr. Paul LaViolette has maintained a successful funding history in Subquantum kinetics, as president and senior researcher of the Starburst Foundation since 1984. Our team is a good recipe for success due to our backgrounds in physics and mathematics, and dedication to this research project.

Paul A. LaViolette, Ph.D. is a physicist and director of the Starburst Foundation: a scientific research institution. He received his BA in physics from Johns Hopkins, his MBA from the University of Chicago, and Ph.D. in Systems Science from Portland State University.

Brendan J. Darrer, Ph.D. is a physicist with a background in electromagnetism and tomography and has undertaken post-doctoral and honorary research associate work in this field at University College London. He has an M.Sc. in particle physics from Royal Holloway College, University of London in 2004, and a B.Sc. (Hons.) in physics from Hertfordshire University in the UK in 2002.

Lumi Pakkanen has a BS.c. and MS.c. in theoretical physics and has done numerical simulations of the Skyrme-Faddeev topological soliton model.

Manny Muro works in Microprocessors and AI systems.

 

Our researchers have experience in seeing through research projects at Ph.D., MS.c. and BS.c. levels. Our lead group member, Dr. Paul LaViolette, has developed SQK from its early beginnings in the 1980’s, and has many journal papers reporting his progress in this field (see above links). Dr. Brendan Darrer has recently completed a Ph.D. in electromagnetic tomography and has an MS.c. in particle physics. Lumi Pakkanen has an MSc in theoretical physics that includes experience with mathematics of vortices.

 

The challenges of this project are as follows. We will run the code Lumi Pakkanen has written, on a cloud platform; adjust the code as required, and analyse the simulations for vortical motion of the ether substrates X, Y and G. Navier-Stokes (fluid dynamics method) has been added to the original Model G, to allow the vortices to take place. Our task will be to show how this relates to quantum spin of an arbitrary neutron like particle, generated by our simulations, using python’s Tensor Flow 2 software. Lumi Pakkanen has already developed the code for this, and as described above, we need to pay for a cloud computing platform, that has enough power and memory, to run these simulations in a short time – to make it feasible to do the research.

story:
We are starting U Thrive Europe – a non-profit organisation which will train and coach teenagers in so-called 21st century skills:

critical thinking, creativity, collaboration, and communication.

Our vision:

empowered, thriving young people

who find innovative solutions  to  the world challenges.

We take deep interest in the current social processes and their impact on the future. The role of today’s young people is striking: their engagement, their will to solve global challenges even if they don’t have the knowledge and the experience of the adults.

We want to reach out to all young people, including those facing extreme hardship: refugees, survivors of human trafficking, those managing health-related challenges. Through our activities, we will encourage them to re-build their link to the society, and not simply survive but thrive in the  life that they choose.

We are four professionals with diverse backgrounds. We got together about a year ago, in Brussels, Belgium. Each one of us had just made a professional life change. Each one was looking for a way to pursue a cause and a dream, while building on their previous professional background: life coaching, diplomacy, project management, international development, theater, sales, and European integration.

Being convinced Europeans, we took seriously the available social research, according to which Europeans score less on soft skills :

 

Teenagers across the EU can do better on key skills like teamwork. We recognize the real need to bring transversal and transferable skills to our youth so that they succeed in their quests today and thrive later, as adults and professionals, on a par with their peers world-wide.

 

Therefore, we started U Thrive Europe. We developed a set of interdisciplinary trainings, based on an all-inclusive concept: one gets to know and manage her/himself and their social relationships (through the training in Emotional Intelligence); one learns to be creative and relate to their immediate social environment (through a course in improvisational theater); and one learns to analyse, make informed choices, convince others, and lead (through a communication/debate training).

With us, today’s young people don’t have to wait for tomorrow, when they get a job, to acquire these soft skills through at-work training, coaching and team-buildings. They will start to build these skills earlier – in their formative years. This is, in fact, the right time when they must acquire them to internalise them easier, and deeper.

Today’s fast paced technological progress brings many new jobs; more traditional, known professions seize to exist. So how can the youth today prepare for jobs that don’t exist? What disciplines to study, what skills to acquire?  Scientific and policy research shows that one solution is to train the young people in so-called transferable and transversal skills – they can  be adapted to different personal and professional paths, including to those that we may not know about just yet. Our trainings will help the young people to develop exactly this kind of ‘soft’ skills.

Crowdfunding will help us to – start up.

We need to gather an initial pool of funding.

We will use it to:

  • Find our audience, ‘place ourselves on the map’ of youth services and activities.
  • Cover the expenses related to the establishment and the initial reach-out of our non-profit.
  • Build ‘channels of distribution’ of our services. We plan for three such channels: online courses, extracurricular activities for secondary schools (on-site, with an online option as a back-up) and own physical classes in a venue tailored to the needs and interests of teenagers.

We already have one client and are actively working on our online training module.

          We aim to gather 10 000 EUR. These will help us cover costs related to:

  • the legal and fiscal registration of our non-profit organisation, under the legislation of the Kingdom of Belgium
  • the preparation of branding and marketing materials
  • developing our presence in the social media – indispensable if we are to reach out to the contemporary young people, and to make it easier for youth in distress to reach us
  • developing our capacity to teach online: crucial if we are to conduct our trainings in COVID and quarantine-ridden times, when the young people may need us to be there for them even more than in healthy times.

If the campaign gathers more funds than expected, the outstanding resources will be used to organise our first training for underprivileged youth. Finally, we would also like to compensate symbolically the young volunteers who have been part of this crowdfunding campaign and those who have been working on the pre-registration phase of our organisation.

If we do not manage to gather the targeted EUR 10K, your support will not be wasted! We will prioritise the elements that allow our initiative to move forward and reach the young people faster, namely the online training capacity and the presence in social media.

Yes, like many people, we want to ‘save  the world’. In our case – by helping as many young people as we can to get today the skills they need - now and tomorrow.

The so-called soft skills, or transversal and transferable skills, have been widely recognized as instrumental to the professional success in 21st century. This kind of skills generally relate to the personality, the character of each one of us.

The World Economic Forum has a body of work proving, among others, that:

(a) almost half of the professions and therefore – the jobs in the near future – do not exist today;

(b) the “human” factor will remain a driving force  in the professions to come, alongside the “digital” factor;

(c) personal/soft skills are one of the five distinctive skill clusters that will be required in the emerging professional fields.

For further reference press here and here.

The World Economic Forum has launched in early 2020 an initiative called "Reskilling revolution". It aims to provide 1 bln people with better education, skills, and jobs by 2030.

The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has been exploring the link between skills and social progress since 2015. They are conducting  a deep study of the social and emotional skills of 10-15-year-old students. Their methodology is science-based and probably the most comprehensive done so far at global level. The results are expected in 2023. We look forward to them.

In Europe, these global trends are well recognized too. So, it is the significance of the 21st century skills or the so-called transversal skills, as means to address them. They are an integral part of a strategy of the European Commission targeting stronger sustainable competitiveness, social fairness and resilience to react to crisis. The European Commission has set up a plan called “European Skills Agenda” which states:

« Beyond technical skills, the labour market increasingly needs transversal skills like working together, critical thinking, and creative problem solving. The increasing influence of robots and algorithms on our labour markets further increases the need for uniquely “human” skills such as empathy and adaptation to change in complex environments. [ … ] While schools have a role to play, they are often developed outside formal learning, at work and throughout life. It can be difficult to identify, recognise and communicate those skills, this is why in the next phase of EU action on transversal skills, more needs to be done to capture them.“

Communication “European Skills Agenda for sustainable competitiveness, social fairness and resilience” (2020)

 In short, it may be difficult to predict what hard skills will be needed in near future, for jobs that do not exist just yet. However, there is a way to respond and to equip the youth of today for the job market of the tomorrow: through systematic training in a broad-based skill-set of transversal, transferable, entrepreneurial skills  that help awaken strategic personal characteristics like agility, grit, leadership, critical thinking, communication, collaboration and creativity. At U Thrive Europe, we contribute to this end.

Social innovation may have become a buzz word. For a good reason, we believe. It brings solutions that address, effectively and sustainably, key challenges of our time. With U Thrive Europe, we aim to bring exactly that, a «new solution to a social problem which is more effective, efficient, sustainable or fairer compared to existing solutions, and which generates value primarily for society instead of single individuals or organisations». [Phills et al. (2008) Rediscovering Social Innovation, accessed through Social Innovation Academy]

We recognize the social need for developing today skills for tomorrow. These skills impact the present well-being and future employability of young people: creativity, curiosity, communication, collaboration, critical thinking, as well as grit, agency, leadership, and adaptability.

Through our interdisciplinary model of training, we address the need for such skills more effectively than the existing solutions.

First, because our concept targets that need directly: through an interdisciplinary learning that gives the students the ability to recognize bias, to think critically, to tolerate ambiguity, as well as to acknowledge and appreciate ethical concerns. Our methodology is based on experiential learning or learning-by-doing. It builds capabilities through reflection on real experience. Our program offers an addition to the – still rather scattered - efforts of the schools, medical/social care and parenting/home education.

To learn more about our course, check the brochures displayed on this website or contact us at contact@u-thrive.org. 

Second, nowadays, training in soft skills is usually offered to professionals, at-work or at earliest in universities – to those who already face the challenges arising from the lack of such skills. People are forced to ‘learn as they go’, which may add stress to their life. U Thrive Europe introduces training in transversal skills to earlier age-groups, so that teenagers and young adults can integrate these skills in their lives and social relations early on, during their formative years.

Third, introducing training in transversal skills earlier will impact the young people not only in the future, but already in their current life. It can improve their academic success and their relations with family and friends. Our trainings can help them interact more safely in social media and find ways to use it to learn and engage in constructive debate.

Finally, we are committed to diffuse our solution through an organisation with a primary social purpose.

U Thrive Europe is a non-profit enterprise. For us training in 21st century skills is not just work. It is a cause. It is about mentoring, about adding to the quality of life, about giving back to those we care about – the young people of today, tomorrow’s adults.

More importantly, we want to bring ‘social survival skills’ to the brave but less fortunate: survivors of human trafficking, refugees, teens overcoming drug addiction or any other crisis or difficulty they are handling in their life. To this end, U Thrive Europe is registered and will operate as a non-profit organisation. The primary purpose of our operation will be to invest in causes and projects that help young people to reconnect with their own self, to reintegrate in the society and to thrive.

U Thrive Europe may be a young organisation, but our trainers stand on a solid base of experience.

Aida is a successful teacher, trainer and ACC/ICF certified life coach. She has over 10 years hands-on experience as project manager in international development.

Tatiana has been a diplomat for 22 years, and an adamant reader and speaker for even longer. She has travelled and negotiated with people from all walks of life in over 15 countries.

Rozana is a professional improvisational and classical actress. She has acted for theatre, TV and cinema, and has been an improv trainer for 12 years.

Simona brings in her sales experience. She is a cunning business administrator and the most efficient promoter of the vision of U Thrive Europe.

Finding your first ‘audience’ is never easy, and Covid-19 made it even more challenging. Low numbers of sign-ups to our classes is probably the main risk that we need to mitigate. However, we do see an opportunity as well, in this volatile situation.

To respond, we have stepped up the preparation for online training. This ‘channel of distribution’ has been a priority for us from the start. In a way, Covid-19 added an argument in favour of it. The U Thrive concept is dedicated to a generation that spends a lot of time online and is bound to function online as adults too. However, extended online presence also brings risks that we are aware of. Our online training is done in engaging and dynamic way. It mitigates the risk that the students are mere recipients/consumers of content. They participate pro-actively, very much like in a session in-person.

We are already offering an online-alternative to the after-school activities for the secondary schools. In this way the students can have an option that allows to contune their journey with us, even though the communication through the screen may not be as rewarding as the exchange in person.

Another solution is to pull forward our plans to apply for funding under EU and other international programs. In the meantime, we will work with disadvantaged youth on a voluntary basis.

Help us spread the word! Donating your time and sharing connections is just as dear to us!

  • Share the link to this campaign and our announcements in Facebook and Instagram!
  • Use the Indiegogo sharing tools too (right under the title on this funding page)
  • Please share with parents and teens you know and who may benefit from our innovative training program!
  • Of course, sharing with people and organisations willing to support initiatives like ours, would be a great help too!

If you have read this far, you are a real hero! We love you!
story_txt:
We are starting U Thrive Europe – a non-profit organisation which will train and coach teenagers in so-called 21st century skills: critical thinking, creativity, collaboration, and communication.Our vision:empowered, thriving young peoplewho find innovative solutions  to  the world challenges.We take deep interest in the current social processes and their impact on the future. The role of today’s young people is striking: their engagement, their will to solve global challenges even if they don’t have the knowledge and the experience of the adults.We want to reach out to all young people, including those facing extreme hardship: refugees, survivors of human trafficking, those managing health-related challenges. Through our activities, we will encourage them to re-build their link to the society, and not simply survive but thrive in the  life that they choose.We are four professionals with diverse backgrounds. We got together about a year ago, in Brussels, Belgium. Each one of us had just made a professional life change. Each one was looking for a way to pursue a cause and a dream, while building on their previous professional background: life coaching, diplomacy, project management, international development, theater, sales, and European integration.Being convinced Europeans, we took seriously the available social research, according to which Europeans score less on soft skills : Teenagers across the EU can do better on key skills like teamwork. We recognize the real need to bring transversal and transferable skills to our youth so that they succeed in their quests today and thrive later, as adults and professionals, on a par with their peers world-wide. Therefore, we started U Thrive Europe. We developed a set of interdisciplinary trainings, based on an all-inclusive concept: one gets to know and manage her/himself and their social relationships (through the training in Emotional Intelligence); one learns to be creative and relate to their immediate social environment (through a course in improvisational theater); and one learns to analyse, make informed choices, convince others, and lead (through a communication/debate training).With us, today’s young people don’t have to wait for tomorrow, when they get a job, to acquire these soft skills through at-work training, coaching and team-buildings. They will start to build these skills earlier – in their formative years. This is, in fact, the right time when they must acquire them to internalise them easier, and deeper.Today’s fast paced technological progress brings many new jobs; more traditional, known professions seize to exist. So how can the youth today prepare for jobs that don’t exist? What disciplines to study, what skills to acquire?  Scientific and policy research shows that one solution is to train the young people in so-called transferable and transversal skills – they can  be adapted to different personal and professional paths, including to those that we may not know about just yet. Our trainings will help the young people to develop exactly this kind of ‘soft’ skills.Crowdfunding will help us to – start up.We need to gather an initial pool of funding.We will use it to:
Find our audience, ‘place ourselves on the map’ of youth services and activities.
Cover the expenses related to the establishment and the initial reach-out of our non-profit.
Build ‘channels of distribution’ of our services. We plan for three such channels: online courses, extracurricular activities for secondary schools (on-site, with an online option as a back-up) and own physical classes in a venue tailored to the needs and interests of teenagers.
We already have one client and are actively working on our online training module.          We aim to gather 10 000 EUR. These will help us cover costs related to:
the legal and fiscal registration of our non-profit organisation, under the legislation of the Kingdom of Belgium
the preparation of branding and marketing materials
developing our presence in the social media – indispensable if we are to reach out to the contemporary young people, and to make it easier for youth in distress to reach us
developing our capacity to teach online: crucial if we are to conduct our trainings in COVID and quarantine-ridden times, when the young people may need us to be there for them even more than in healthy times.
If the campaign gathers more funds than expected, the outstanding resources will be used to organise our first training for underprivileged youth. Finally, we would also like to compensate symbolically the young volunteers who have been part of this crowdfunding campaign and those who have been working on the pre-registration phase of our organisation.If we do not manage to gather the targeted EUR 10K, your support will not be wasted! We will prioritise the elements that allow our initiative to move forward and reach the young people faster, namely the online training capacity and the presence in social media.Yes, like many people, we want to ‘save  the world’. In our case – by helping as many young people as we can to get today the skills they need - now and tomorrow.The so-called soft skills, or transversal and transferable skills, have been widely recognized as instrumental to the professional success in 21st century. This kind of skills generally relate to the personality, the character of each one of us.The World Economic Forum has a body of work proving, among others, that:(a) almost half of the professions and therefore – the jobs in the near future – do not exist today;(b) the “human” factor will remain a driving force  in the professions to come, alongside the “digital” factor;(c) personal/soft skills are one of the five distinctive skill clusters that will be required in the emerging professional fields.For further reference press here and here.The World Economic Forum has launched in early 2020 an initiative called "Reskilling revolution". It aims to provide 1 bln people with better education, skills, and jobs by 2030.The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has been exploring the link between skills and social progress since 2015. They are conducting  a deep study of the social and emotional skills of 10-15-year-old students. Their methodology is science-based and probably the most comprehensive done so far at global level. The results are expected in 2023. We look forward to them.In Europe, these global trends are well recognized too. So, it is the significance of the 21st century skills or the so-called transversal skills, as means to address them. They are an integral part of a strategy of the European Commission targeting stronger sustainable competitiveness, social fairness and resilience to react to crisis. The European Commission has set up a plan called “European Skills Agenda” which states:« Beyond technical skills, the labour market increasingly needs transversal skills like working together, critical thinking, and creative problem solving. The increasing influence of robots and algorithms on our labour markets further increases the need for uniquely “human” skills such as empathy and adaptation to change in complex environments. [ … ] While schools have a role to play, they are often developed outside formal learning, at work and throughout life. It can be difficult to identify, recognise and communicate those skills, this is why in the next phase of EU action on transversal skills, more needs to be done to capture them.“Communication “European Skills Agenda for sustainable competitiveness, social fairness and resilience” (2020) In short, it may be difficult to predict what hard skills will be needed in near future, for jobs that do not exist just yet. However, there is a way to respond and to equip the youth of today for the job market of the tomorrow: through systematic training in a broad-based skill-set of transversal, transferable, entrepreneurial skills  that help awaken strategic personal characteristics like agility, grit, leadership, critical thinking, communication, collaboration and creativity. At U Thrive Europe, we contribute to this end.Social innovation may have become a buzz word. For a good reason, we believe. It brings solutions that address, effectively and sustainably, key challenges of our time. With U Thrive Europe, we aim to bring exactly that, a «new solution to a social problem which is more effective, efficient, sustainable or fairer compared to existing solutions, and which generates value primarily for society instead of single individuals or organisations». [Phills et al. (2008) Rediscovering Social Innovation, accessed through Social Innovation Academy]We recognize the social need for developing today skills for tomorrow. These skills impact the present well-being and future employability of young people: creativity, curiosity, communication, collaboration, critical thinking, as well as grit, agency, leadership, and adaptability.Through our interdisciplinary model of training, we address the need for such skills more effectively than the existing solutions.First, because our concept targets that need directly: through an interdisciplinary learning that gives the students the ability to recognize bias, to think critically, to tolerate ambiguity, as well as to acknowledge and appreciate ethical concerns. Our methodology is based on experiential learning or learning-by-doing. It builds capabilities through reflection on real experience. Our program offers an addition to the – still rather scattered - efforts of the schools, medical/social care and parenting/home education.To learn more about our course, check the brochures displayed on this website or contact us at contact@u-thrive.org. Second, nowadays, training in soft skills is usually offered to professionals, at-work or at earliest in universities – to those who already face the challenges arising from the lack of such skills. People are forced to ‘learn as they go’, which may add stress to their life. U Thrive Europe introduces training in transversal skills to earlier age-groups, so that teenagers and young adults can integrate these skills in their lives and social relations early on, during their formative years.Third, introducing training in transversal skills earlier will impact the young people not only in the future, but already in their current life. It can improve their academic success and their relations with family and friends. Our trainings can help them interact more safely in social media and find ways to use it to learn and engage in constructive debate.Finally, we are committed to diffuse our solution through an organisation with a primary social purpose.U Thrive Europe is a non-profit enterprise. For us training in 21st century skills is not just work. It is a cause. It is about mentoring, about adding to the quality of life, about giving back to those we care about – the young people of today, tomorrow’s adults.More importantly, we want to bring ‘social survival skills’ to the brave but less fortunate: survivors of human trafficking, refugees, teens overcoming drug addiction or any other crisis or difficulty they are handling in their life. To this end, U Thrive Europe is registered and will operate as a non-profit organisation. The primary purpose of our operation will be to invest in causes and projects that help young people to reconnect with their own self, to reintegrate in the society and to thrive.U Thrive Europe may be a young organisation, but our trainers stand on a solid base of experience.Aida is a successful teacher, trainer and ACC/ICF certified life coach. She has over 10 years hands-on experience as project manager in international development.Tatiana has been a diplomat for 22 years, and an adamant reader and speaker for even longer. She has travelled and negotiated with people from all walks of life in over 15 countries.Rozana is a professional improvisational and classical actress. She has acted for theatre, TV and cinema, and has been an improv trainer for 12 years.Simona brings in her sales experience. She is a cunning business administrator and the most efficient promoter of the vision of U Thrive Europe.Finding your first ‘audience’ is never easy, and Covid-19 made it even more challenging. Low numbers of sign-ups to our classes is probably the main risk that we need to mitigate. However, we do see an opportunity as well, in this volatile situation.To respond, we have stepped up the preparation for online training. This ‘channel of distribution’ has been a priority for us from the start. In a way, Covid-19 added an argument in favour of it. The U Thrive concept is dedicated to a generation that spends a lot of time online and is bound to function online as adults too. However, extended online presence also brings risks that we are aware of. Our online training is done in engaging and dynamic way. It mitigates the risk that the students are mere recipients/consumers of content. They participate pro-actively, very much like in a session in-person.We are already offering an online-alternative to the after-school activities for the secondary schools. In this way the students can have an option that allows to contune their journey with us, even though the communication through the screen may not be as rewarding as the exchange in person.Another solution is to pull forward our plans to apply for funding under EU and other international programs. In the meantime, we will work with disadvantaged youth on a voluntary basis.Help us spread the word! Donating your time and sharing connections is just as dear to us!

Share the link to this campaign and our announcements in Facebook and Instagram!

Use the Indiegogo sharing tools too (right under the title on this funding page)
Please share with parents and teens you know and who may benefit from our innovative training program!
Of course, sharing with people and organisations willing to support initiatives like ours, would be a great help too!
If you have read this far, you are a real hero! We love you!

story:
Change the way your children learn at home with AR Micro-Blocks. It’s an easy-to-use modular device that turns your smartphone or tablet into an augmented reality-enabled microscope.

 

 

 

 

Using the microscope blocks, attach the AR-enabled slides to your smart device and watch as animated organisms appear. All of your organisms are stored in the app’s “lab” where you can access them at any time! 

The app also includes games, virtual experiments and other activities, just follow the on-screen directions for detailed instructions and explanations!

 

 

 

AR Micro-Blocks includes three objective lenses: 60x, 150x, and 300x.

The lenses are optimized for smartphones and offer high quality with a mass reduction in size and weight that makes them efficient to carry around. Plus, you can use the three lenses individually to access the macro-photography feature.

 

Similar to a traditional microscope, the illuminator provides an essential light to ensure you’re getting the best quality when viewing your objects. 

Use the illuminator block with the slide holder and the 150x or 300x lens for the ultimate viewing experience.

 

 

The slide block allows you to insert an industry-standard sample slide to view your objects! 

Attach the slide holder to the illuminator block along with the 150x or 300x lens for the microscope capability. You can then easily add a dish to the slide holder to collect and view your liquid sample!

 

 

 

 

 

Eastcolight Hong Kong Limited is one of the largest exporters of educational toys in Hong Kong. For 30 years, Eastcolight has been dedicated to developing new educational toys and tools that can help kids learn from anywhere in the world. Our mission is to provide “Harmony, Honesty, Innovation, and Excellence” to our customers and inspire children’s interest in science and nature. Our products are made with supreme quality and innovation and fully comply with the highest safety standards in the toy industry.

 

 

We can’t thank you enough for checking out our project and helping us make AR Micro-Blocks a reality. 

We know not everyone will be able to support us with a pledge, so even if you can’t give a dollar or pre-order an AR Micro-Blocks set, if you’re a supporter of AR Micro-Blocks, you can help us spread the word on Twitter, Facebook, Reddit, Instagram and anywhere else you can think of!

story:
A Short Summary

As a contribution to the important global reflective process of the Commission on the Status of Women meeting at the United Nations in New York from March 9-20th 2015, the Riverside Coalition (a progressive faith-based gathering) is inviting four women leaders from very different backgrounds and experiences, to share their positions on why two separate movements, fighting against gender and LGBT inequality, need to work more closely together to achieve their missions.

Composed of several major ecumenical and faith traditions, the Riverside Coalition is seeking to build deeper dialogue on the intersection of health, education and business development with gender and LGBT equality. Both movements have been challenged in recent years with a backlash from religious conservative organizations and denominations/ International progress on the alleviation of extreme poverty cannot go forward without a clearly articulated counter-narrative that integrates faith values with the human rights agenda. More recently, moves to redefine the family and “traditional values” at the United Nations have caused more polarization on previously agreed strategies to give more access to women to reproductive rights and remove constitutional and legal barriers in 80 countries which perpetuate stigma and discrimination against LGBT people and women and girls. Without some agreement around values and outcomes, these legal and cultural barriers, often supported by religious understanding of gender and sexual roles and beliefs, will continue to be a stumbling block to progress on achieving many of the outcomes in the spirit of the Millennium Development Goals and the ability to include important issues in the development of their successors, the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG’s).


Why is this an important gathering?

Twenty years on from the groundbreaking meeting in Beijing, the Commission offers a global opportunity to see how the human family is treating its daughter's, wives and grandmothers. Every cry we hear is a cry of the future.

It is important to give people of faith an opportunity to build connections between women's and LGBT - and the wider issues of access to health, business opportunities and ending all forms of violence and discrimination. Four women will be invited to attend many of the events and networking opportunities as well as build long term support for their extraordinary programs. The long term goal of this project is to create a new pool of expertise to confront religious extremism with tangible workable models of economic empowerment and equal access for LGBT people and women. We need the funds to assist the Coalition and international guests to travel to New York, provide hospitality and introductions to additional supporters while educating us on the issues they face every day. How are religious institutions supporting their missions and how are they hindrances?

A Public Witness

On Friday March 13th, the Riverside Coalition will host a panel discussion at the Riverside Church entitled “Women of Faith, Women of Doubt”. The four panelists will be sharing insights into their work on building support and collaboration between LGBT and gender equality issues in four different contexts and will open up the panel presentations to the CSW delegation and public at large. The four panelists are:

Maxensia Nakibuuka is a community activist living with HIV from Kampala Uganda. She has served as a local political leader and is Chair of the Council of the Laity in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Kampala. In 2012, she was one of 500 civil society representatives at the UN to discuss the future global AIDS plan and has spoken about the effects of criminalization of people with HIV and LGBT and other vulnerable and populations. She has spoken at panels at CSW on the importance of community health home based care for women and at the World Bank on the need for collaboration at the grass roots level for all women – transgender, bisexual and lesbian and straight women. She is developing an important economic model involving a gay/straight alliance in Kampala. In 2014, the Catholic Archbishop invited her to head the Archdiocesan HIV programs and she will be presenting both the positive effects of religious support for health and some of the negative effects of religious discrimination. 

Andy Kopsa is a freelance investigative reporter based in New York City. She has written for Al Jazeera, The Atlantic, Talking Points Memo, The Nation, Ms. magazine, and many other publications. She was awarded a 2012 Society of Professional Journalists Award for investigative reporting and was a 2013 recipient of a Knight Grant for Reporting on Religion in American Public Life from USC Annenberg.  Andy has done extensive work reporting on LGBT and women's rights issues internationally especially Sub-Saharan Africa as well as throughout the United States.  Andy has done extensive research and reporting on the US Government funding anti-gay and anti-women's rights groups and has spoken at several conferences and consulted with many human rights groups on the subject.  

Angeline Cecelia Jackson is Executive Director of Quality of Citizenship Jamaica and remains one of five open lesbians in the whole of Jamaica. She has spoken at the World Bank about issues affecting women and LBT women in particular –the focus of her organization. She has a strong religious background but the current attitudes of religious leaders in Jamaica has made it very difficult for her to support any particular religious tradition or denomination.

Dr. S. N. Nyeck is Assistant Professor at Clarkson University, Potsdam New York. She had to seek political asylum in the USA following a legal battle in Cameroon where she was publicly outed as a lesbian and subsequently had to flee for her safety. Some of the earliest formulations of LGBT identity and news from Cameroon on the underground LGBT movement came from Sybille’s writings and experience.

Dr. Nyeck is a graduate of Swarthmore College and holds a Ph.D. in political science from the University of California Los Angeles. She is interested in comparative analysis of government contracts with particular focus is on theorizing and modeling the intersection of law, politics, and human agency in the public sector. Dr. Nyeck is the founder of Africa’s Public Procurement and Entrepreneurship Research Initiative (www.apperi.org) and the co-editor of Sexual Diversity in Africa: Theory, Politics, and Citizenship (McGill-Queen’s University Press 2013). She received the Ruskin Prize and many awards for highest academic achievements including the title of a Distinguished Alumna of the City University of New York, The Pat Hussain Justice Award, and The Edward Said /Audre Lorde Scholar Activism Award.

The Panel will be Moderated by Rev. Canon Albert Ogle, President of the St Paul's Foundation for International Reconciliation, who has worked in all of the countries represented by the panelists. 

A reception in honor of the international guests will be held at the Riverside Church and funds raised will also go towards covering the costs of the reception and this intensive two week networking opportunity.
Please reserve your ticket(s) for this limited event and reception sponsored by St. Paul's Foundation, the Riverside Church, Unitarian Universalist UN Office, Muslims for Progressive Values and The Presbyterian Church's UN Mission.

http://www.eventbrite.com/o/hosts-st-pauls-foundation-the-riverside-church-maranatha-unitarian-universalist-uno-office-presbyterian-office-at-the-un-muslims-for-progressive-values-6474062413?s=34423788

The Impact

The Riverside Coalition intends to continue meeting and providing whatever support we can to the development of a strong progressive faith presence at the UN while supporting efforts of these courageous women on the ground in Uganda, and Jamaica. We plan to produce a report for our supporters and funders when the conferences are over.

Each presenter will also have time to develop a three year strategic plan with our network and to gain access to potential donors and supporters in favor of LGBT/Women's alliances.

International journalist Andy Kopsa is building community awareness for these cross cutting issues and panelists will be available to local and international media covering the event.

We hope these witnesses will encourage the UN on the journey for LGBT and gender equality and the situation in 80 countries where gender issues are criminalized (often through equal access for property rights for women and criminalization for same gender sexual conduct).


Risks & Challenges

Each one of these women takes an enormous personal risk, to their safety, their reputations and professional development when they speak or write about these issues. We show our solidarity and are inspired by their courage. Without more tangible economic and moral support from individual donors and supporters, their missions will remain on the margins of their countries and their voices diminished. Both LGBT and gender equality movements will continue to loose ground and support at the UN and there will be increasing pressure from conservative religious organizations to enforce the interpretation of holy texts and their gender roles on millions of people who may not share these precepts because of their own religious or ethical values. Women's Reproductive Rights can no longer be guaranteed as a given in these international conversations and often the same interpretations and imposition of religious tradition and law are increasingly being used against both LGBT and women. It is also important for women in differing cultures to be aware of the particular needs and suffering of lesbians and transgender women, as well as the increasing persecution and stigma experienced by heterosexual women allies.

We see this three week experience as the beginning of an important educational process and we need the resources to make sure it happens and there will be follow up and additional opportunities to continue the dialogue and partnerships.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot financially support this project, please share this appeal with your friends, faith communities and on your social media networks.
Pay attention to the news during the Commission on the Status of Women and offer appropriate responses to media coverage and to your elected officials on what you are hearing, reading and seeing. The erosion of human rights under the disguise of religious freedom or cultural values needs to be stopped and called what is really is - sectarianism, sexism and homophobia. Be a part of the change and support the work of the Riverside Coalition.

the ground in Uganda, and Jamaica. We plan to produce a report for our
supporters and funders when the conferences are over.
Each presenter will also have time to develop a three year strategic plan with our network and to gain access to potential donors and supporters in favor of LGBT/Women's alliances.
International journalist Andy Kopsa is building community awareness for these cross cutting issues and panelists will be available to local and international media covering the event.
We hope these witnesses will encourage the UN on the journey for LGBT and gender equality and the situation in 80 countries where gender issues are criminalized (often through equal access for property rights for women and criminalization for same gender sexual conduct).

  Risks & ChallengesEach one of these women takes an enormous personal risk, to their safety, their reputations and professional development when they speak or write about these issues. We show our solidarity and are inspired by their courage. Without more tangible economic and moral support from individual donors and supporters, their missions will remain on the margins of their countries and their voices diminished. Both LGBT and gender equality movements will continue to loose ground and support at the UN and there will be increasing pressure from conservative religious organizations to enforce the interpretation of holy texts and their gender roles on millions of people who may not share these precepts because of their own religious or ethical values. Women's Reproductive Rights can no longer be guaranteed as a given in these international conversations and often the same interpretations and imposition of religious tradition and law are increasingly being used against both LGBT and women. It is also important for women in differing cultures to be aware of the particular needs and suffering of lesbians and transgender women, as well as the increasing persecution and stigma experienced by heterosexual women allies.We see this three week experience as the beginning of an important educational process and we need the resources to make sure it happens and there will be follow up and additional opportunities to continue the dialogue and partnerships.
  Other Ways You Can Help
If you cannot financially support this project, please share this appeal with your friends, faith communities and on your social media networks.Pay attention to the news during the Commission on the Status of Women and offer appropriate responses to media coverage and to your elected officials on what you are hearing, reading and seeing. The erosion of human rights under the disguise of religious freedom or cultural values needs to be stopped and called what is really is - sectarianism, sexism and homophobia. Be a part of the change and support the work of the Riverside Coalition.

story:
Thanks to everyone who donated! Our campaign is over, but you can visit us at Media Poetry Studio for updates on our July 2015 Summer Camp.

MEDIA POETRY STUDIO: GIRLS NEED TECH

Hi! We are three Poets Laureate from Santa Clara County: David Perez, Erica Goss, and Jennifer Swanton Brown. We are poets and teachers, and have each worked with helping young people find their voices as writers.

We started Media Poetry Studio as a summer camp to provide artistic young women in Santa Clara County with the opportunity to produce high quality short films inspired by their own, original poetry.

Even though we live in Silicon Valley, women are vastly underrepresented in technology fields. We wanted to do something significant to address that fact. You can be part of our effort to help young women develop confidence, empowering them to excel in the realms of art and technology.

In order to make the camp as successful as possible, we are asking for $5000 to purchase camera equipment and accessories. Here is an itemized list of all of the equipment we hope to acquire along with prices (after tax):


1 Video Camera (Panasonic GH4)

$1,629

1 Lens (Panasonic Lumix G 12-35mm)

$977

1 Small Diaphragm Microphone (Audix SCX1/HC)

$543

1 Shotgun Microphone (Sennheiser ME66/K6)

$501

1 Microphone Adapter/Amplifier (JuicedLink RM222)

$358

4 Memory Cards (SanDisk Extreme Pro 64 GB)

$330

1 Monopod (Manfrotto 500 series)

$304

1 Audio Recorder (Zoom H4N)

$218

4 Camera Batteries (Panasonic DMW-BLF19)

$208

TOTAL

$5,068


We have some great perks for our supporters. We have cool T-shirts that you can wear to show your support, and hoodies for when the weather gets cooler. At the $100 level, we offer a T-shirt and a student-written haiku. David and Erica are published authors, and have autographed books for people who donate $250. Please check out all of the gifts we have!

If we don’t reach our goal, we will use the funds we receive to purchase the best camera we can with the money we have.

We established Media Poetry Studio to address a critical need: the lack of women’s participation in technology-related fields. Women are still underrepresented in major Silicon Valley companies, and too many girls stand on the sidelines while boys participate in computer classes, video games, and science fairs.

Our group is well-qualified to make Media Poetry Studio a success. Jennifer Swanton Brown has taught with the California Poets in the Schools since 2000, bringing poetry instruction to schoolchildren in the Bay Area. David Perez runs poetry workshops for youth that include writing and spoken word. Erica Goss taught high school poetry for five years, and ran a poetry camp for teens. Our partners are California Poets in the Schools and Poetry Center San Jose, so we are in good company!

Please let your friends know about Media Poetry Studio. Help us get the word out about getting young women involved in technology and art! You can use the IndieGoGo Share tools to make this as easy as possible.

Thank you!

Erica, David and Jennifer

story:
About My Campaign 



None of the world's problems (ranging from climate change, the environment, education to human rights) can be solved in one fell swoop. But by investing in the education of the future of humanity, we increase the chances that tomorrow's adults have the tools to solve those problems effectively.


Kofi Annan and Jeff Sachs at a Millennium Village  with their XOs and showing them off in support of innovative education for children 

The Ebola Crisis You DIDN'T Hear About: 'Education'. Have you ever imagined about what the life is like for the over 4 thousand Sierra kids who don't have Ebola, but whose lives have been turned upside down by the Ebola Epidemic? The defeat of Ebola means Education over Ebola, for Education is that which liberates.


What we need
Login Promise: Our goal is to deliver innovative education to Sierra Leone children  whose schools were hampered and who are made orphans as a result of the effects of the Ebola outbreak. We’re a non-profit organization bringing free digital educational content to the world’s underprivileged children through community access ICT centres where they can learn skills, grow their minds and share their stories to the world. 


Login promise will provide educational opportunities Sierra Leone children affected  by Ebola by bringing free digital educational content to the world’s underprivileged children.  Login Promise will also  be replicated in Liberia and Guinea in the near future. We are targeting 1600 kids in  Sierra Leone develop technological and life skills. The project is an appropriate intervention at this time.
There will be ICT teachers who will help to mentor children and train them in the use of their new gadgets for educational purposes. The training will help in sustainable  innovative education and social progress of the children and add value to their lives, paving a way to a national innovation education drive.

Founder testing the One Laptop per child computers at the International Student Conference Education Without Borders hosted by the Higher Colleges of Technology in Abu Dhabi 2007. B-Gifted Founder Andrew Benson Greene was a Guest Speaker  

  • The Cost
  • The program will involve the setting up of two B-Gifted Information Communication Technology (ICT) access centers for children and will be equipped with computers, scanners, printers, chairs tables,  which involves 30 workstations at a cost of $26,500 for each ICT centre which makes a sub- total of $53,000
  • Training, materials and administrative cost is $12,000 which adds up to $65,000
  • B-Gifted will cover the configuration and analytics costs for each computers
  • A private donor has agreed to pay for shipping
  • And because private donors cover our R&D and tech development costs, public donations go entirely 100% to expanding our field work
  • We will issue tax receipts for donations
  • MAKE IT A GIFT: Donate support to #LoginPromise in someone's honor, and we'll give them the perks, put their name on the devices, and tell them about your generous gesture. Just email b.giftedfoundation@gmail.com if you want to do this. 


Proof of Impact


"B-Gifted Foundation has been a powerful organization for change especially for children in  fragile educational system.  From my experience since I started working with the children with B-Gifted, children have been greatly encouraged to learn and be come innovative thinkers and also helping freely to create their dreams. They are a shining example of the hope that education brings - (Maxwell Adew) B-Gifted Consultant.

"ICT Community Access centres will continue to become the principal information and educational window to our community's children impacted by the Ebola." Martin Kailie MPhil, (B-Gifted Associate).


It will be a great advantage for education in emergencies and a huge success for children to leapfrog the personal huddles of lack of access to educational materials by introducing innovative ICT programs and reach many children. This will be a remarkable positive reach to children who will be excited and overwhelmed by this program and who can no longer wait to get themselves fully engaged by encouraging the  children affected by Ebola outbreak to have access to the internet and educational materials. The children will login and communicate to other children around the world on relevant social issues which are affecting them. They will learn from other cultures and share their experiences with students in far away countries in a cross-cultural edifying exchange of ideas. They will even engage in a global classroom in which they will pose questions to teachers in the global classroom. B-Gifted hope to continue the campaign long after the Ebola crises to enable innovative education to continue in positively transforming lives in the small West African country that has been scarred by war and Ebola. (Andrew Benson Greene) when he was summoned

as  Guest Speaker during the International Student Conference

"Education Without Borders 2007'. Abu Dhabi UAE
Why it Matters (The Impact)
There are thousands of children in Sierra Leone and millions more around the world that lack access to a quality education. We see the 'Login Promise Project' as an exciting opportunity opening up to use affordable technology to link these children with the great educational materials that are available freely online and a chance to connect with students around the world. B-Gifted foundation believes that education is a human right and technology can be used as a means not an end.
What our organization has done so far
The organization www.b-gifted.org has successfully implemented projects that have indeed served the common good and this project will further expand on those gains. With the significant experience of staff in the field as well as successful track record, and previous recognition like the Pan African Awards for entrepreneurship in Education and the ITU Telecom Awards, we hope to succeed.


My organization continues to develop new ways for youth to cope with the effects of war and diseases through overcoming barriers of communication between youth in conflict and conflict-free zones. Some of my newest programs help youth communicate about and overcome the tragedies of war through art, creative writing, music recording and video production. I have been asked to travel to over 26 countries to present on my groundbreaking approach by not only rehabilitating children from war, but also providing training in 21st century skills that the former child soldiers and amputee victims will be able to use to create a stable and peaceful society.
 My Story.

Founder with children in SIERRA LEONE donating Teddy bears to kids at the amputee camps for the show some love project
I have been a powerful model for peace and education. Having seen the war years and though my life has been surrounded with violence and war, I continually chose to pursue actions that lead to education and peace. My efforts have changed countless lives during and after the war, and my innovative education programs and rehabilitation techniques have caught the attention of world leaders. I was a natural leader before the war, a member of my school’s drama group, a columnist for my school newspaper and a school prefect. At a young age, I was sent to a boarding school in Southern Sierra Leone, but even there I was not safe due to the war. Like many youth who came of age during the war, the lack of opportunities and the psychological effects of the war violence damaged the stability of an entire generation. Instead of giving in to the violence and chaos, I chose to become a leader of positive change in my community and decided to educate children and youth about actions and attitudes of peace. While at the refugee camp, I began teaching English and literature to the other refugees. I also used my spare time to volunteer with local human rights and peace education organizations creating peace and advocacy materials. As the war stretched on I furthered my own education by earning a Bachelor’s degree in English Civil Law and International Relations from the University of Sierra Leone. Though the civil war still continued after my graduation I jumped into the opportunity of founding educational programs for children. I began with transporting former child soldiers to internet cafés and then slowly acquired recycled computers and low cost technology that could be used to provide the youth with access to the internet. After training the youth, I encouraged them to use their new skills to exchange ideas about peace education online as a way to cleanse their thoughts from the agonies of war. Slowly the youth began recovering from the war and redirecting their energy towards becoming positive agents in social issues around them. My programs continued to grow and I was able to reach out to non-profit organizations to acquire new educational technologies and grow my education and recovery training programs. Now, if there was ever anyone who had reason to be resentful, despairing, and bitter, in seeing all the tragic situations of children in wars, it could have been I.

Founder with children in SIERRA LEONE donating Teddy bears to kids at the amputee camps for the show some love project


Charles F. Harper, Director of Outreach at the MY HERO Project in the summer of 2002 has this to say about  Andrew and his education and peace work when Andgrew got selected as My Hero in the My Hero Project.

"Now, if there was ever anyone who had reason to be resentful, despairing, and bitter, it is Andrew. Raised in a country that was divided by the violence of civil war, where brother fought against brother and sister against sister, and children were recruited to do horrific acts of violence for the self-interests of greedy leaders, he watched as an entire international community ignored the pains and struggles of his fellow countrymen as if they were not even a blip on the international radar screen.

He could easily have chosen the path of blaming others for the tragic circumstances of his country and the impossibilities of educating himself and the young people around him. He could have wallowed in self-pity, never moving a muscle to rebuild a destitute country. He could have clung to the status quo of survival for survival's sake. Instead, Andrew chose the road less traveled.

When you meet Andrew you get to know someone who is at peace with himself and the world. There is a serenity in his presence. And the serenity comes from Andrew having the courage and the faith to nurture the gifts and talents he has as an educator and to share those talents and gifts with all who come within the universe of his indomitable spirit. That serene smile comes from not believing but knowing that one step, one day at a time, his children's children will experience the impossible possibility of peace, justice and freedom from the scars of war."

Thank you!

Founder of B-Gifted Andrew Benson Greene was a Young Digital Innovator at the UN ITU  TELECOM WORLD 2011  in Geneva, Switzerland presenting his winning pitch on 'Digital Hope'


 useful links
 www.bgiftedfoundation.cfsites.org
www.b-gifted.org 

 http://www.sierraexpressmedia.com/?p=31752 

https://www.behance.net/gallery/24149707/The-co... 

http://about.me/andrewgreenejr 


 Recognition

story:
Pathfinders Ranch is a small residential treatment center located in Driftwood, TX. We are a non-profit organization that serves boys who have experienced severe trauma due to abuse and neglect. As a result, these children are unable to manage the stressors of day to day life, and are unable to experience a normal childhood. They lead transient lives, transitioned from place to place, never developing meaningful, lasting or nurturing relationships with adults. For these young boys there was no light at the end of the tunnel.

In 1973 Pathfinders opened its doors with a mission to promote healing and hope in a safe, nurturing environment, to promote healthy relationships and mentoring. To help these young boys build self-esteem, viable skills and pro-social behaviors. For however long we are blessed with their presence, we strive to teach these children that there are adults they can trust, that there are safe places in this world and that they can accomplish whatever they set their minds to.

Pathfinders Ranch sits on 25 acres with 100 year old stone buildings.  There are separate school buildings, office buildings, living quarters, and social and meal buildings and camping areas in the far back part of the property.  We currently are using our personal cell phones to contact each other.  As you can imagine, cell services can be hit or miss out here. The boys and their counselors are never all in the same place, and rarely near the main office where visitors check in.  We really need two way-radios.  Not only will they provide better, more efficient communication between the office and staff, but will also allow for urgent or emergency communications between staff who are also spread out across the property with different groups of boys.  As you might imagine with a 501(c)3 non-profit, all available funding goes to provide for our boys, and not much is left over for things like this. 

The $500 being requested will allow us to purchase 10 two-way radios, the base chargers, ear pieces, backup batteries, and the required FCC license.  Should we not get all of the funding requested, we will buy fewer radios, as many as can be purchased with whatever we receive.  Thank you for your consideration.
