story:
Short Summary

Let me introduce myself. My name is Sheila Neijman, director of heart4happiness. I believe that everyone deserves to be happy and healthy. It's my mission to bring people at a higher level of consciousness and closer to the laws of human nature for a significant improvement on health, happiness and wellbeing. To realize my mission:

Ik wil mij graag even voorstellen. Mijn naam is Sheila Neijman, oprichtster van Heart4happiness. Mijn missie is global happiness: volwassenen en kinderen naar een hoger geluksbewustzijn brengen met een significante verbetering op gezondheid, geluk en vitaliteit. Om mijn missie vorm te geven heb ik jou hulp nodig.

I need your support!

I want to emphasize the importance of emotional and health metrics to achieve my goal. The science behind it, developed a sophisticated technology, that has a huge effect on people happiness, health and wellbeing. For me it's time to start right now.

Have you ever dreamed about a unique and highly advantage scan for a totally body and mind experience? To reduce stress and increase an overall feeling of happiness? Now it's possible! 

Without your support I can’t start working with this amazing technology: "The Oberon pathfinder". I have been working hard to educate myself in training with the technology. Now I am a licensed trainer and need your help to purchase the Oberon Pathfinder to be able to integrate it's incredible techniques into my work, and re-introduce positivity into peoples lives from an amazing new level. It’s that simple! How can you support me?

  • You can help me by posting this project on Social Media.
  • You can deposit an amount.
  • Or you can do both:-)

Thank for your support, whatever your choice may be.

Onlangs ben ik afgestudeerd als being in balance coach.  Being in Balance® wordt door velen beschouwt als een van de krachtigste coachingsvormen die op dit moment in de wereld beschikbaar zijn. Geen coaching vorm ter wereld gaat zo snel naar de essentie en is zo goed meetbaar op effectiviteit, zelfs tot op DNA niveau.

Being in Balance® richt zich met zeer geavanceerde technologie, via een body-mind scan van maximaal 10 minuten snel op de kern van de zaak. Gewoon met je kleding aan worden er zo 90 miljard punten in je lijf gemeten. Zo ontstaat er in korte tijd een nauwkeurig beeld over waar je in balans bent en waar mogelijk niet.

Daarmee helpen we kinderen, volwassenen en professionals effectief op individuele basis door het vinden en doorbreken van belemmerende patronen en innerlijke saboteurs. We creëren in korte tijd een verhoogd bewustzijn en activeren bronnen voor een betere balans en prestatie. Op deze manier bereiken we gemiddeld een stressreductie van 40% en bereik je op een versnelde manier jouw ‘next level’ van prestatie, geluk  en vitaliteit.

The magnitude of what you as a contributor will help achieve

  • 90 billion measuring points in your body.
  • State-of-the-art technology! Designed on the basis of the biophotons measurement.
  • The Technology deliver detailed illustrations and a good visualisation.
  • The technology can support me as a coach in preparing a therapy regime, you quickly discover the core of your mental case to mak a hugh step in happiness.
Every body cell is built like a hyper sensitive antenna. It receives information from its environment and passes these on again. Without this exchange of information there would be no life on earth. Biophotons control this flow of information. Those are measurable as a noise field which surrounds the body (often also referred to as aura). The cells virtually work together like a big orchestra: every cell sends out oscillations (sound) which altogether build up a melody. The more damaged a cell is, the less information it has and the more disharmonious is its sound and the less its sound fits the melody. 

What We Need & What You Get

The money will be spent for the purchase of the Oberon Pathfinder technology worth 30,000 euros. I'll lease the technology for a few years. After that I hope to be able to pay the remaining amount.

The perks that I offer are amazing for you. They will help you grown to a higher level of health and consciousness. It's amazing what this technology can do.

Already the ancient Chinese said: “Life is an oscillation around the inner centre” and Albert Einstein stated: “Each aspect of life is oscillation”. Every human being, every animal, every stone, every organ, every cell, every cell nucleus, every bacterium and every virus has an optimal harmonious oscillation. This natural oscillation is physically measurable. The OBERON System capitalises on this knowledge.

If I do not Achieve my goal, I will lease the technology and i will work hard to be able to acquire the technology and thus help children and adults to be healthier and more positive in life. 

The Impact

The Oberon Pathfinder is an incredible, creative and innovative technology, made by Metavital. The Oberon system is a naturopatic diagnostic system with makes use of the non linear system analysis (NLS). It is cerrificated according tot the German Medical Device Act (MPG) and designed for  the alternative medicine. It is an ideal link for us between the thousand of years old Eastern art of healing and the modern naturopathy.

I tested a couple of times in practice, during my being in balance coach education, and it delivers amazing results.

The technology looks at the whole person (physical, emotional, mental and spiritual) and is able to level essentially to identify the root causes of imbalance and help these recover.

The technology is the result of over 50 years of Science research. The fact that this technology is now also available for children, adults and professionals is very valuable.

A total of 90 billion points are measured in the body. During the measurement the recorded measurements are mathematically compared with a database of over 30,000 frequency patterns intertwined with each other. The interpretation and analysis of the curves, text and energy values you learn as a Coach quickly come to the crux of the matter and directed to intervene in the main "levers": the 20% that determines 80% of the result.

A vast scientific literature has detailed how negative emotions harm the body. Serious, sustained stress or fear can alter biological systems in a way that, over time, adds up to “wear and tear” and, eventually, illnesses such as heart disease, stroke, and diabetes. This technology has a preventive starting point.

Very effective for coaching sessions for individuals, but also for groups. For instance: children gain more strength, self assurance and balance at school. Or employees who are now able to measure, optimize and improve each of the metrics so that they can be happy as possible. Employees who are in balance are happier and also more productive, that's been proven many times, so it's important that leaders try their best to make sure every employee is in balance and happy as possible. If you want to improve your happiness and wellbeing levels, this technology is for you.

How does it work?

The Oberon system works on the basis of biophotons, the system is safe from the human genetic perspective. It is comfortable for clients and absolutly pain free.

Every body cell is built like a hyper sensitive antenna. It receives information from its environment and passes these on again. Without this exchange of information there would be no life on earth. Biophotons and scalar waves control this flow of information. These are measurable as a noise field which surrounds the body (often also referred to as aura). The cells virtually work together like a big orchestra: every cell sends out oscillations (sound) which altogether build up a melody. The more damaged a cell is, the less information it has and the more disharmonious is its sound and the less its sound fits the melody. You go so quickly to the heart of the matter.

The information medicine refers to that as the so-called degree of deviation: The cell deviates from its "normal" state and is weakened.

Take a look at this link for visual info.

Test it yourself and work on your own performance, vitality, mobility or happiness.

In order to experience the wide range of application possibilities of Oberon, I am offering you the opportunity to test it. Unfortunately it isn't possible to offer Scan-coaching to everyone who makes a donation. But if you continue reading you'll see that I offer other great rewards to express my gratitude for your funding. Do you have another suggestion, please tell me.

We aim to bring people to a higher level of consciousness and closer aligned to the universal laws of nature. We do this with empathy through training, coaching of individuals, and consultancy on managing change in organizations. Our ultimate goal is to contribute to a significant improvement in health, happiness and wellbeing of all people and nature.

References “With special appreciation for the Coaching technology - it is an important part of our evolution - for it can heal our world!” Bruce Lipton PhD, International leader in bridging Science and Spirit.

Risks & Challenges

As a coach it is important to be well balanced in order to learn to apply the personal processes and the technology.

This gives an important element in personal growth and awareness to the coach and client.

By itself to build success experiences with the technology and thus also to go to a higher level of performance, you can better empathize with the customer. Walk your talk is an important principle and value.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Who we are

Rural Women Initiative (RWI) is a charitable non-profit organization for young women and mothers aged 12-35 years in rural communities.

Rural Women Initiative was established in February 14th 2013 by 4 young mothers with support of Kikandwa Environmental Association. In response to the difficulties facing women and girls due to violence, poverty and lack of education.

Our mission is to advocate for gender equality appreciating rural womens significance in their community by empowering them economically through education and health programs.

Child marriage leads girls to become pregnant too early, drop out of school exposing them to HIV/AIDS, maternal mortality and a life of inescapable poverty.

Women can be the most important catalysts for change in their children’s lives. By empowering women—through education, skills training, improved healthcare, or providing skills and resources to set up a small business—we can improve children’s health, education and future opportunities as well as impact the wellbeing of the entire community both economically and physically.

How ICT (Information and Computer Technology) will assist Rural Womens Iniciative.

RWI is determined to reach our goals improving the lives of women and through them their communities through education, training and empowerment programs, one of the programs we would like to offer is a course in ICT.(information computer technology)

We currently lack the technological capacity to raise funds and bring global and local attention to our worthy cause.

We need computers not only for the administration of the venture but also as a means to provide a platform where we can teach women skills in the use of computers and the internet as part of a sustainable skill set they can use to improve their lives and employability in an ever more technology driven world.

ICTs have been promoted by international organizations such as UNESCO, UN WOMEN and the FAO as a poverty reduction strategy with the additional benefit of empowering women in developing countries.


Women's access to ICTs is restricted in some countries. Low levels of literacy, limited technological access, technical expertise and the often poor infrastructure and high cost of connectivity in developing nations, prevent many women from taking full advantage of the opportunities offered by ICTs.

We all want to learn but there's only one computer.

 Rural Women Initiative (RWI) would like to reverse this situation in Kikandwa Sub County. We are posting a campaign  to fundraise US$10,000 (28749643.92UG) to buy equipment (computers, modems and a printer as well as the ongoing cost of internet connection of approximately US$100/month)in order to train women on the positive use of ICT to develop their livelihoods. RWI will partner with Kikandwa Environmental Association (KEA) to grant it office space to house the computers.

The school

 Any additional moneys collected will be put towards our other ventures such as   KEA school, orphanage, well building, tree planting and agricultural work and workshops.

We are asking for the sum of USD$10 000

What your money will do:

$1 will plant 5 trees address climate change/soil erosion

$3 will support Doctors reaching homes to treat patients

$5 will support a child and mother with HIV/AIDS with ARV”S or medical care

$10 will train farmer in computers

$20 will train a farmer in agriculture

$25 will pay one month electricity

$30 will feed a person too elderly/infirm to work for one month

$20 will cover medical expenses of elderly/infirm for one month

$50 will Stock computer lab with ICT books and resources

$53 will will support a child at school with school fees and scholastic materials

$60 will buy 1 modem

$65 will support the local trainer/teacher for one month

$100 will support an orphan including food school medical

$100 will pay for one month internet connection

$1000 will buy one computer package

$1200 will pay to finish the well to be used by the community to save people from walking 4km for water, the excess water after domestic use will be used for irrigating the crops that feed the community.

Potable water for 500 people 4km walk away the road for women is full of danger.


We started digging the well by hand with funds raised by the community will you help us?

What do we do?

RWI works in rural communities that are affected by socio-economic constraints which forces parents to send female children into early marriage exposing them to risks of HIV /AIDS maternal mortality and a life of inescapable poverty.

We build and strengthen their capacity and capabilities to address:

  • Antenatal and postnatal access

  • HIV/AIDs diagnosis/treatment

  • Food security and farm conservation technologies

  • Girl child education

  • Entrepreneurship skills in order to empower and rebuild economic skills improving their lives commercially and domestically.

  • Address the cycle of poverty through education, skills and training

Our Objectives

The overall need of the community is to empower girls, and through them the wider community by ensuring women and children enjoy their right to an education and participation in a violence-free environment using shared overall strategic approaches towards the achievement of some common objectives

  • To increase understand of the legal and policy framework that specifically addresses violence against women and girls in schools in Kikandwa .Sub county in Mityana District.

  • To reduce Violence against girls by family members, teachers and peers in the district.

  • To increase girls’ enrolment and keep the girls in school to satisfactory levels.

  • To form girl clubs to demonstrate confidence challenging the culture of violence in and around schools, report incidents and create peer support networks.

  • Eradicating poverty in homesteads as women are recognised to be strong pillars in development and improving communities.

  • Empowering the girls through provision of quality and practical education.

  • Imparting practical skills to enable women compete favorably in the job market.

  • Empower single and young mothers to be self-reliant.

  • To serve as an alternative educational opportunity. Accommodate girls who drop out of school due to poverty.

  • To serve as an extension program to formal education.

  • To serve as a gateway to skill improvement. Promoting the notion of self-reliance.

  • To serve as a research center to continue to understand and serve the needs of the community.

  • Strengthening womens capacity in leadership, entrepreneurship and economic empowerment.

  • Improve our capacity to achieve and deliver our targeted objectives.

  • To be a leading driver and advocate in the struggle for equality through advocacy, training and capacity building in Uganda.

In school not Marriage.

In order that we may continue to provide expand our programs and reach the most vulnerable people we rely on the donations from you, the public to achieve and further our goals so that the next generations are better equipped to progress in life and work their way out of poverty and all the problems it creates. We understand that not everyone can afford to donate but with your help through social media you can help us get our mission out to the world .

THANK YOU!!


In case you are still reading and would like to know more about the school and life in Uganda.
A word from our Director and Executive Director .

KEA GREEN HILL EDUCATION CENTRE

Background

KEA Green Hill Educational Centre (KEA GHEC) was established in 2004 at the hill with the mango trees, to carry out a pilot project on education in Kasejjere village.

Before the establishment of the school, the nearest primary school was at a distance of seven kilometers walk. KEA’s school reduced the distance for children to walk, making education more accessible.

The school is open for all children; including those who are orphans or from vulnerable families and cannot afford the school fees. The school now has 250 pupils, of which sixty are from vulnerable families and forty are orphans.

KEA GHEC’s mission is to provide quality education to the pupils and teach the importance and management of the environment and natural resources.

The school has its own gardens and nursery beds. Unfortunately the school’s vegetable gardens have dried up due to the water shortage, but there are plans to create a water pond to harvest water for irrigating vegetables.

The pupils are educated on the environment through lectures, songs, and several activities like cleaning up the school ground, planting seedlings, taking care of the gardens to learn about food security, and the anthill project, through which the effects of

Despite its good work, the school has not received any funding and it currently still lacks facilities such as an office, classrooms, desks and blackboards.

The devoted teachers are paid little. 30,000 Ugandan shillings (Euro 12,13.6 USD, 17.49AUD) a month, the school pays for their meals and provides hospitable accommodation.

KEA Green Hill Educational Centre is a truly genuine and authentic school, struggling to make it. The formation of an executive committee contributed to the expansion of activities.

The Director John Kaganga has been there since the beginning, and this has benefited the organisation a lot. The Director is a hardworking man who makes a lot of personal sacrifices for KEA.

Many people interviewed spoke out their gratitude for what the community means to them and has helped them.

Students in the nursery bed 

KEA Green Hill Education Centre School is a Private School encompassing Primary education for boys and girls from entry level to Year 15.

We are located in Kasejjere Village Kikandwa Sub county Mityana District Uganda but draw an attendance from a broader area.

KEA GHEC School started and was launched in 2004 with four teachers and only volunteer students, the school has grown to almost 250 students. The student roll is predominantly from the lower socio-economic areas of Kikandwa.

KEA School is passionate about academic and character excellence. This is recognized through the delivery of the Ugandan and International curriculum, which is the basis of academic development to shape the whole person. We are blessed with a fiercely dedicated staff.

Their professionalism and an “anything is possible” attitude create a powerful environment for growth. Importantly, community partnership between school, family and international volunteers of support that ensures each child gets the best possible start in life.

Here, we specialize in the character and academic development of children.

Formal education plays a fundamental role in identifying, developing and maximizing the unique gifts and talents children inherently possess.

From the earliest possible age, we partner with parents to develop a clear pathway for our students throughout their entire schooling life, up to employment.

KEA GHEC is a powerful community, the school school along with our vibrant local community patterns teach the ethos which is our community.

Collectively, we create a culture of sound values and convictions so children know they they have a special purpose in life.

We believe in our students, and as a consequence they marinate in an environment that is positively geared towards success. We don’t just encourage success, we celebrate it.

Our Director John Kaganga, After 20 years of teaching and living with community, is honored to work alongside like-minded professionals who are passionate about our approach, and about the future of the children.

Education is not just about teaching, it’s about investing into the lives of tomorrow’s leaders.

Education is a lifelong journey, and I’m tremendously privileged to be a part of it for the next generation.


 A teacher takes nursery kids through a lesson

KEA has now been running a child sponsorship program since 2004.

We believe in child sponsorship because it connects people like you with children that are miles away, and gives you the opportunity to develop a unique personal relationship with your sponsor child.

Each sponsor child gets the opportunity to go to school, a new school uniform, lunchtime meals where possible, exercise books and stationary, and access to First Aid. You can sponsor a child in KEA Green Hill Education Centre and give them a future today.

Life in Kasejjere Village is a struggle for anyone, but the life of a child is even harder.

Imagine, growing up in a world where you lack the very basics in life, food, clean water, medicine, shelter, safety, a bed of your own.

Beyond that, there are no toys, no dolls, and no soccer balls, no sweets and treats, at best, a bed of reeds to sleep on.

School would be wonderful to attend, the path out of poverty, but there is no money for school fees, so you stay home and wait for a miracle, but for most there is none, life is simply survival, staying alive.

Death is very common to you (20% of Ugandan children do not reach the age of six).

Life is hard, and yet, most of the world is unaware of your difficulty or that of any of Ugandan’s child.

They are amongst the voiceless of the world, needing others to speak on their behalf, and my attempt to be voice for the voiceless, KEA Green Hill Education children.


Growing up in Kikandwa rural community

Growing up anywhere brings its share of problems, but growing up in a place like  Kikandwa rural community is a struggle that is beyond imagination.

Put yourself into the shoes of Ugandan child; I should say feet, (many children do not wear shoes, but might wear sandals, flip–flops as I call them).

You are fortunate to be still alive at the age of six, many of your friends have died of things such as malaria, dysentery, malnutrition, and the like.

The fact that both father and mother are alive is another miracle. Life expectancy for men is 40 years in Uganda and 42 years for women (rarely do you encounter gray haired men.)

Malaria is still the number one killer in Uganda, but AIDS comes into second place.

Wherever one goes, one can see the evidence of the ravages of AIDS. Go into any school and ask how many children have only one parent, or no parent and you would be astounded.

Orphans of AIDS

In a country like Uganda with a population of 36 million, there are as many as 1.5 million AIDS orphans. Yes, there is malaria and other illnesses.

This is the other war, AIDS, the silent killer that sweeps through offices, villages, banks, schools and government institutions.

In fact many businesses refuse to give time off for more than one funeral a month to their employees, since death comes so frequently to families.

A story of a child in Kasejjere

So here you are, a child in Kikandwa, living in a small house, made of sun baked, mud bricks, covered by a corrugated tin roof (they are called iron sheets here), that leaks whenever it rains.

The room is small, yes, the house is one room, and if you are really lucky it will be two. No kitchen, you have a stove outside, a charcoal one, charcoal costs about 7 dollars (£5) a bag and for some that lasts all month.

If you have no money you find some wood and use a fire to cook over. The bathroom, consists of an outhouse down the path, shared by many families, there is a common one used by the men and by all to wash in.

Most Ugandans bathe using plastic wash–tubs twice a day. A house like that rents for 10 to 20 dollars a month in an urban center like Kikandwa, and it is in slum areas of town.

The income of your parents is only about 40 dollars combined. Father works on farm for a well to do family from 7 in the morning to 7 evening. Mother goes off at 6:30 in the morning to work as a maid for someone in rich family and on farms.

You are a girl of 12, and now you are home alone, well almost.

Father might sleep for a few hours, but then he is off into town seeing if he can come up with some extra work and make a few more Shillings for the family.

Why are you not in school? Oh, the answer to that one is easy, a girl does not need school, she only needs to take care of the house, get a husband when she is older, have babies, raise a family, cook, maybe work as maid, or in a restaurant, but there is no reason to invest in a woman or so the thinking goes. (Most of the lack of education for girls has to do with economics, the firstborn boy is usually sent to school if any money is available.)

Your oldest brother left at 7 that morning, he had to take a roll of toilet paper to school, since the day before he was scolded for not having any. He also had to take a new broom to class to sweep the classroom and the school grounds after school.

School is expensive.

A new law had been passed in 1997 making Ugandan school free through primary grades, but then there are all those other fees, such as PTA, Building Funds, extra this and that. Besides school is six miles away and the mini bus called taxi costs 50 cents each way.

There are the hidden costs that no one talks about at school, but are so common.

Class size is often about 100 students to the room.

Even that is supposed to change but has not. Mother had to come up with extra money so that your brother could pay the teacher to sit up at the front of the class, where he could hear and learn better.

Money had also to be paid to have homework checked and corrected, and if you wanted extra help called tutoring for the Primary 7 exam, there was something extra for that.

That is why only one of your brothers goes to school, while the others hang around until maybe some of the uncles and aunts in the family can contribute something for the education of them.


For that is how it works in Uganda, no family can ever come up with the money alone, it takes combined resources of the extended family to send children to school in most cases.

Daily, it is your job, to look after the little ones. Do laundry in two plastic tubs with water that you had to carry in a 5–gallon can up a hill to the house. Not only washing, but there is cooking.

You do not have to worry about preparing meat, there is no money for that, except a few times a month. The shop is just around the corner from you. No, you can’t ask for a cut of meat, you get what is there and the price is the same. You really do not care about that chewy, tough meat anyway, plus it is covered with flies, yuck.

Live chickens can be bought in the market, but they are expensive, costing between four and five dollars. It is only on special occasions that one will buy them, it is your job to kill and pluck clean if your brothers are not around.

The main staple of Uganda is Matooke (green bananas, masked and steamed under banana leaves) and Posho made from corn flour.

Every evening you buy a plastic sack of milk, for immediate consumption, since it would spoil if you bought it during the day. It is sold along the roads by vendors with carts, and if you pick one from the bottom of the pile, it is still reasonably cool, well warm.

Bread, can also be bought there from the same roadside hawkers who call out what they have for sale, as it gets dark small oil lamps illuminate their wares.

In the mornings it is your job to head to the market to buy stalks of bananas, some sweet potatoes if any money is on hand.

There are also red kidney beans, but during the two rainy seasons of the year they may be filled with maggots and you do not like getting your meat and protein that way, but that is reality and what can one do.

Rice is available but you have to pick the rocks out of it since it is no fun chewing on them. It is also very expensive. There are potatoes which you like and sometimes use when you buy beef, but it always comes down to how much money the family has.

The future does not look bright for you.

You hear people talking about things getting better, but you have not seen it. Malaria still comes to visit you on a regular basis, there is dysentery, cholera that one has to look out for, and as you have gotten older and developed as a young woman has, there is the hidden problem in Africa.

Your uncle has been coming around saying things to you, and suggesting that you come to visit him and learn how to be a woman. Yes, things are not getting better for you.

It would be nice to learn how to read and write, but it may never happen, in fact that are not many in the family that do.

There are only two ways out of the slum in which you live. One is to get an education and the other way is what your Aunt is doing, selling herself to White and Indian men who have money and just might take you in as a live in girlfriend.

That however is not the way you learned in your church, just up the path from your slum called Eden Revival where they spoke of Holiness, right living and faith in God to bring about a future with hope. You have had a lot of hope, prayed a lot, but not seen the bright future, but then God must be busy in other parts of the world.

You like going into town with your mother to Kikandwa market where you see clothes for sale, not that you get many, it has been some time since you last gotten a new skirt, and the detergent had long ago washed out all the brightness that had been there (Omo does get the dirt out, but also the color).

You reach down to scratch your feet, and notice that a few more jiggers have lodged themselves there and it would be time again to cut them out, since there was no money to go the doctor, and mother did a good enough job with a knife.

Fun, for you was playing with other children, going down to the place where the men drank out of common pot the homebrew that some of the women prepared.

There you could dance to drums with some the other girls. You liked it and everyone would join in while the old men would talk about yesterday, today and tomorrow, always looking for that miracle to help them out of the slum.

A new lottery had come to Kikandwa and Uncle Stephen had taken all of his salary of 30 dollars, (30,000 shillings) and bet it and won nothing in return. Others laughed about it but you felt sorry for him.

There was something new you had heard about. Kikandwa Environmental Association organization set up a little office and temporary classes in Kasejjere community and was signing up children to go to school without school fees.

They also provided school uniforms, books, t and some food to most vulnerable children. The cost would be paid for a by a family far away and it was called sponsorship. Maybe, just maybe this was true and someone did care about children like you maybe there was more to life; maybe there would be a chance, an open door to have hope. Maybe, someone did care. 

The reality is that you and I can make the difference in the lives of children in Kikandwa. You can go there like I and many others have done and actually work amongst them, or you can contribute your money to an agency that will do so on your behalf.

There is a catch however.

Often only a small portion can reach the child who really needs the help, so one has to ask questions, such as how much of your money goes to actually supporting your child? How much of it is used in administration, fundraising and so on, goes toward the child and its development in Uganda. which is why this campaign is so important to us 


Meet Namukuye Nooren

Noreen is now around 5 years old. She lives in Uganda in a Village called Kasejjere. Noreen doesn't stay with her parents as her father passed away in a car accident and her mother was a prostitute in the village and passed away recently.

One day Noreen elderly sister heard that there was free education at a local school and so she came along to see if she could apply. 200 other children turned up with their parents or guardians but there were only 30 places. Noreen’s sister like many others was turned down.

However she was not going to give up, so she came back each day hoping that she would be accepted. For two weeks she kept coming back to the school and each day she would be sent home.

I was at that school and watched as children stood for hours hoping that they would receive something as basic as an education. I was amazed at how many turned up looking for something which we take so much for granted.

That was when I decided that I should do something, and KEA was birthed. I said that I would get sponsors for five children.

I would go home and tell the people here that we need to do something.

The next day five children turned up to the school hoping to be accepted but expecting to get sent away.

This time they didn't get sent home. Today they would start school.

That was when I met John Kaganga. Noreen has now been attending school for two years and she hopes that someday she will look after her Grandmother and get a job where she doesn't have to be a prostitute.


KEA now sponsors well over 15 children and supports each year. Here are just some of those children: Through the support of many generous people, and the hard work of numerous young people in schools, churches and youth groups, KEA has raised over US$ 5000 in the past ten years to help build temporary buildings, and support many children in need. Any donations we received will be put to excellent use helping this wonderful dynamic hard working community .
story_txt:
Who
we are 


Rural
Women Initiative (RWI) is a charitable non-profit organization for
young women
and
mothers aged 12-35 years in rural communities.

Rural
Women Initiative was established in February 14th 2013
by 4 young
mothers with support of Kikandwa Environmental Association. In
response to the difficulties facing women and girls due to violence,
poverty and lack of education.
Our
mission is to
advocate
for gender
equality
appreciating
rural womens significance
in their community by empowering them economically through education
and health programs.Child marriage leads girls to become pregnant too early, drop out of school exposing them to HIV/AIDS, maternal mortality and a life of inescapable poverty.Women
can be the most important catalysts for change in their children’s
lives. By empowering women—through education, skills training,
improved healthcare, or providing skills
and resources to
set up a small business—we can improve children’s health,
education and future opportunities as
well as impact the wellbeing
of the entire community both economically and physically.



How
ICT (Information and Computer Technology) will assist Rural Womens
Iniciative.

RWI
is determined to reach our goals improving the lives of women and
through them their communities through education, training and
empowerment programs, one of the programs we would like to offer is a
course in ICT.(information computer technology) 


 We
currently lack the technological capacity to raise funds and bring
global and local attention to our worthy cause. 


We
need computers not only for the administration of the venture but
also as a means to provide a platform where we can teach women skills
in the use of computers and the internet as part of a sustainable
skill set they can use to improve their lives and employability in an
ever more technology driven world. 


ICTs
have been promoted by international organizations such as UNESCO, UN
WOMEN and the FAO as a poverty reduction strategy with the additional
benefit of empowering women in developing countries. 


Women's
access to ICTs is restricted in some countries. Low levels of
literacy, limited technological access, technical expertise and the
often poor infrastructure and high cost of connectivity in developing
nations, prevent many women from taking full advantage of the
opportunities offered by ICTs.We all want to learn but there's only one computer.
 Rural
Women Initiative (RWI) would like to reverse this situation in
Kikandwa Sub County. We are posting a campaign  to
fundraise US$10,000 (28749643.92UG) to buy equipment (computers,
modems and a printer as well as the ongoing cost of internet
connection of approximately US$100/month)in order to train women on
the positive use of ICT to develop their livelihoods. RWI will
partner with Kikandwa Environmental Association (KEA) to grant it
office space to house the computers.

The school
 Any
additional moneys collected will be put towards our other ventures
such as   KEA school,
orphanage, well building,
tree planting and agricultural work and workshops.


We
are asking for the sum of USD$10 000 




What your money will do:


$1
will plant 5 trees address climate change/soil erosion


$3
will support Doctors reaching homes to treat patients 



$5
will support a child and mother with HIV/AIDS with ARV”S or medical
care


$10
will train farmer in computers


$20
will train a farmer in agriculture


$25
will pay one month electricity


$30
will feed a person too elderly/infirm to work for one month


$20
will cover medical expenses of elderly/infirm for one month


$50
will Stock computer lab with ICT books and resources


$53
will will support a child at school with school fees and scholastic
materials


$60
will buy 1 modem


$65
will support the local trainer/teacher for one month 



$100
will support an orphan including food school medical 



$100
will pay for one month internet connection


$1000
will buy one computer package 



$1200
will pay to finish the well to be used by the community to save people
from  	walking 4km for water, the excess water after domestic use will be used for irrigating
the crops that 	feed 	the community.


Potable water for 500 people 4km walk away the road for women is full of danger.
We started digging the well by hand with funds raised by the community will you help us?




What
do we do?

RWI
works in rural communities that are affected by socio-economic
constraints which forces parents to send female children into early
marriage exposing them to risks of HIV /AIDS maternal mortality and a
life of inescapable poverty. 


We
build and strengthen their capacity and capabilities to address:



	Antenatal
	and postnatal access



	HIV/AIDs
	diagnosis/treatment



	Food
	security and farm conservation technologies



	Girl
	child education



	Entrepreneurship
	skills in order to empower and rebuild economic skills improving their lives commercially and domestically.



	Address
	the cycle of poverty through education, skills and training 
	






Our
Objectives

The
overall need of the community is to empower girls, and through them
the wider community by ensuring women and children enjoy their
right to an education and participation in a violence-free
environment using shared overall strategic approaches towards the
achievement of some common objectives



	To
	increase understand of the legal and policy framework that
	specifically addresses violence against women and girls in schools
	in Kikandwa .Sub county in Mityana District.



	 To
	reduce Violence against girls by family members, teachers and peers
	in the district.



	To
	increase girls’ enrolment and keep the girls in school to
	satisfactory levels.



	To
	form girl clubs to demonstrate confidence challenging the culture of
	violence in and around schools, report incidents and create peer
	support networks.



	Eradicating
	poverty in homesteads as women are recognised to be strong pillars
	in development and improving communities.



	Empowering
	the girls through provision of quality and practical education.



	Imparting
	practical skills to enable women compete favorably in the job
	market.



	Empower
	single and young mothers to be self-reliant.



	To
	serve as an alternative educational opportunity. Accommodate girls
	who drop out of school due to poverty.



	To
	serve as an extension program to formal education.



	To
	serve as a gateway to skill improvement. Promoting the notion of
	self-reliance.



	To
	serve as a research center to continue to understand and serve the
	needs of the community.


Strengthening
	womens
	capacity in leadership, entrepreneurship and economic   empowerment.





	Improve
	our capacity to achieve and deliver our targeted objectives.



	To
	be a leading driver and advocate in the struggle for equality
	through advocacy, training and capacity building in Uganda.



In school not Marriage.

In
order that we may continue to provide expand our programs and reach
the most vulnerable people we rely on the donations from you, the
public to achieve and further our goals so that the next generations
are better equipped to progress in life and work their way out of
poverty and all the problems it creates. We understand that not everyone can afford to donate but with your help through social media you can help us get our mission out to the world .


THANK YOU!!


In case you are still reading and would like to know more about the school and life in Uganda.
A word from our Director and Executive Director .



KEA
GREEN HILL EDUCATION CENTRE  


Background


KEA
Green Hill Educational Centre (KEA GHEC) was established in 2004 at
the hill with the mango trees, to carry out a pilot project on
education in Kasejjere village.


 Before
the establishment of the school, the nearest primary school was at a
distance of seven kilometers walk. KEA’s school reduced the distance for
children to walk, making
education more accessible.


 The
school is open for all children; including those who are orphans or
from vulnerable families and cannot afford the school fees. The
school now has 250 pupils,
of which sixty are from vulnerable families and forty are orphans.


KEA
GHEC’s mission is
to provide quality education to the pupils and teach the importance
and management of the environment and natural resources. 



The
school has its own gardens and nursery beds. Unfortunately the
school’s vegetable gardens have dried up due
to the water shortage,
but there are plans to create a water pond to harvest water for
irrigating vegetables.


The
pupils are educated on the environment through lectures, songs, and
several activities like cleaning up the school ground, planting
seedlings, taking care of the gardens to learn about food security,
and the anthill project, through which the effects of


Despite
its good work, the school has not received any funding and it
currently still lacks facilities such as an office, classrooms, desks
and blackboards. 



The
devoted teachers are paid little. 30,000 Ugandan
shillings
(Euro 12,13.6
USD, 17.49AUD)
a month, the school pays for their meals and provides hospitable
accommodation. 



KEA
Green Hill Educational Centre is a truly genuine and authentic
school, struggling to make it. The formation of an executive
committee contributed to the expansion of activities. 



The
Director John Kaganga has been there
since the beginning, and this has benefited the organisation a lot.
The Director is a hardworking man who makes a lot of personal
sacrifices for KEA. 

Many
people interviewed spoke out their gratitude for what the community
means
to them and has helped them.




Students in the nursery bed 






















KEA
Green Hill Education Centre School is a Private School encompassing
Primary education for boys and girls from entry level to Year 15.


We
are located in Kasejjere Village Kikandwa Sub county Mityana District
Uganda but draw an attendance from a broader area.


 KEA
GHEC School started and was launched in 2004 with four teachers and
only  volunteer students, the school has grown to almost 250
students. The student roll is predominantly from the lower
socio-economic areas of Kikandwa.


KEA
School is passionate about academic and character excellence. This is
recognized through the delivery of the Ugandan and International
curriculum, which is the basis of academic development to shape the
whole person. We are blessed with a fiercely dedicated staff. 



Their
professionalism and an “anything is possible” attitude create a
powerful environment for growth. Importantly, community partnership
between school, family and international volunteers of support that
ensures each child gets the best possible start in life.


Here,
we specialize in the character and academic development of children. 



Formal
education plays a fundamental role in identifying, developing and
maximizing the unique gifts and talents children inherently possess.


From
the earliest possible age, we partner with parents to develop a clear
pathway for our students throughout their entire schooling life, up
to employment. 



KEA
GHEC is a powerful community, the
school school along
with our vibrant local
community patterns teach
the ethos which is our
community. 



Collectively,
we create a culture of sound values and convictions so children know
they they have a special purpose in life.


We
believe in our students, and as a consequence they marinate in an
environment that is positively geared towards success. We don’t
just encourage success, we celebrate it.


Our
Director John Kaganga, 
After 20 years of teaching and living with community, is honored to
work alongside like-minded professionals who are passionate about our
approach, and about the future of the
children.


Education
is not just about teaching, it’s about investing
into the lives of tomorrow’s leaders.


Education
is a lifelong journey, and I’m tremendously privileged to be a part
of it for the next generation.



 A teacher takes nursery kids through a lesson

KEA
has now been running a child sponsorship program since 2004. 


We
believe in child sponsorship because it connects people like you with
children that are miles away, and gives you the opportunity to
develop a unique personal relationship with your sponsor child.

Each
sponsor child gets the opportunity to go to school, a new school
uniform, lunchtime meals where possible, exercise books and
stationary, and access to First Aid. You can sponsor a child in KEA
Green Hill Education Centre and give them a future today. 

Life
in Kasejjere Village is a struggle for anyone, but the life of a
child is even harder.

Imagine,
growing up in a world where you lack the very basics in life, food,
clean water, medicine, shelter, safety, a bed of your own.

Beyond
that, there are no toys, no dolls, and no soccer balls, no sweets and
treats, at best, a bed of reeds to sleep on. 


School
would be wonderful to attend, the path out of poverty, but there is
no money for school fees, so you stay home and wait for a miracle,
but for most there is none, life is simply survival, staying
alive.Death
is very common to you (20% of Ugandan children do not reach the age
of six). 


Life
is hard, and yet, most of the world is unaware of your difficulty or
that
of any of Ugandan’s child. 


They
are amongst the voiceless of the world, needing others to speak on
their behalf, and my attempt to be voice for the voiceless, KEA Green
Hill Education children. 






Growing
up in Kikandwa rural community

Growing
up anywhere brings its share of problems, but growing up in a place
like  Kikandwa rural community is a struggle that is beyond imagination.

Put
yourself into the shoes of Ugandan child; I should say feet, (many
children do not wear shoes, but might wear sandals, flip–flops as I
call them).

You are fortunate to be still alive at the age of
six, many of your friends have died of things such as malaria,
dysentery, malnutrition, and the like.

The
fact that both father and mother are alive is another miracle. Life
expectancy for men is 40 years in Uganda and 42 years for women
(rarely do you encounter gray haired men.)
Malaria
is still the number one killer in Uganda, but AIDS comes into second
place.
Wherever
one goes, one can see the evidence of the ravages of AIDS. Go into
any school and ask how many children have only one parent, or no
parent and you would be astounded.

Orphans of AIDS

In
a country like Uganda with a population of 36 million, there are as
many as 1.5 million AIDS orphans. Yes, there is malaria and other
illnesses.


This
is the other war, AIDS, the silent killer that sweeps through
offices, villages, banks, schools and government institutions.
In
fact many businesses refuse to give time off for more than one
funeral a month to their employees, since death comes so frequently
to families.



A
story of a
child in Kasejjere

So
here you are, a child in Kikandwa, living in a small house, made of
sun baked, mud bricks, covered by a corrugated tin roof (they are
called iron sheets here), that leaks whenever it rains. 


The
room is small, yes, the house is one room, and if you are really
lucky it will be two. No kitchen, you have a stove outside, a
charcoal one, charcoal costs about 7 dollars (£5) a bag and for some
that lasts all month. 


If
you have no money you find some wood and use a fire to cook over. The
bathroom, consists of an outhouse down the path, shared by many
families, there is a common one used by the men and by all to wash
in.

Most
Ugandans bathe using plastic wash–tubs twice a day. A house like
that rents for 10 to 20 dollars a month in an urban center like
Kikandwa, and it is in slum areas of town. 


The
income of your parents is only about 40 dollars combined. Father
works on farm for a well to do family from 7 in the morning to 7
evening. Mother goes off at 6:30 in the morning to work as a maid for
someone in rich family and on farms.You
are a girl of 12, and now you are home alone, well almost.

 Father
might sleep for a few hours, but then he is off into town seeing if
he can come up with some extra work and make a few more Shillings for
the family. 


Why
are you not in school? Oh, the answer to that one is easy, a girl
does not need school, she only needs to take care of the house, get a
husband when she is older, have babies, raise a family, cook, maybe
work as maid, or in a restaurant, but there is no reason to invest in
a woman or so the thinking goes. (Most of the lack of education for
girls has to do with economics, the firstborn boy is usually sent to
school if any money is available.)Your oldest brother left at
7 that morning, he had to take a roll of toilet paper to school,
since the day before he was scolded for not having any. He also had
to take a new broom to class to sweep the classroom and the school
grounds after school.School is expensive.

A
new law had been passed in 1997 making Ugandan school free through
primary grades, but then there are all those other fees, such as PTA,
Building Funds, extra this and that. Besides school is six miles away
and the mini bus called taxi costs 50 cents each way. 


There
are the hidden costs that no one talks about at school, but are so
common.

Class
size is often about 100 students to the room. 


Even
that is supposed to change but has not. Mother had to come up with
extra money so that your brother could pay the teacher to sit up at
the front of the class, where he could hear and learn better.

Money
had also to be paid to have homework checked and corrected, and if
you wanted extra help called tutoring for the Primary 7 exam, there
was something extra for that. 


That
is why only one of your brothers goes to school, while the others
hang around until maybe some of the uncles and aunts in the family
can contribute something for the education of them.

For
that is how it works in Uganda, no family can ever come up with the
money alone, it takes combined resources of the extended family to
send children to school in most cases.
Daily, it is your job,
to look after the little ones. Do laundry in two plastic tubs with
water that you had to carry in a 5–gallon can up a hill to the
house. Not only washing, but there is cooking.

You
do not have to worry about preparing meat, there is no money for

since it would spoil if you bought it during the day. It is sold
along the roads by vendors with carts, and if you pick one from the
bottom of the pile, it is still reasonably cool, well warm.

what they have for sale, as it gets dark small oil lamps illuminate
their wares.In the mornings it is your job to head to the
market to buy stalks of bananas, some sweet potatoes if any money is
on hand.

are also red kidney beans, but during the two rainy seasons of the

meat and protein that way, but that is reality and what can one do.

 Rice
is available but you have to pick the rocks out of it since it is no
fun chewing on them. It is also very expensive. There are potatoes
which you like and sometimes use when you buy beef, but it always
comes down to how much money the family has.The future does
not look bright for you.

You
hear people talking about things getting better, but you have not
seen it. Malaria still comes to visit you on a regular basis, there
is dysentery, cholera that one has to look out for, and as you have
gotten older and developed as a young woman has, there is the hidden
problem in Africa. 

Your
uncle has been coming around saying things to you, and suggesting
that you come to visit him and learn how to be a woman. Yes, things
are not getting better for you.
It would be nice to learn how
to read and write, but it may never happen, in fact that are not many
in the family that do. 


There
are only two ways out of the slum in which you live. One is to get an
education and the other way is what your Aunt  is doing, selling
herself to White and Indian men who have money and just might take
you in as a live in girlfriend.
That
however is not the way you learned in your church, just up the path
from your slum called Eden Revival where they spoke of Holiness,
right living and faith in God to bring about a future with hope. You
have had a lot of hope, prayed a lot, but not seen the bright future,
but then God must be busy in other parts of the world.
You
like going into town with your mother to Kikandwa market where you
see clothes for sale, not that you get many, it has been some time
since you last gotten a new skirt, and the detergent had long ago
washed out all the brightness that had been there (Omo does get the
dirt out, but also the color). 

You
reach down to scratch your feet, and notice that a few more jiggers
have lodged themselves there and it would be time again to cut them
out, since there was no money to go the doctor, and mother did a good
enough job with a knife.Fun, for you was playing with other
children, going down to the place where the men drank out of common
pot the homebrew that some of the women prepared.
There
you could dance to drums with some the other girls. You liked it and
everyone would join in while the old men would talk about yesterday,
today and tomorrow, always looking for that miracle to help them out
of the slum.
A new lottery had come to Kikandwa and Uncle
Stephen had taken all of his salary of 30 dollars, (30,000 shillings)
and bet it and won nothing in return. Others laughed about it but you
felt sorry for him.There was something new you had heard
about. Kikandwa Environmental Association organization set up a
little office and temporary classes in Kasejjere community and was
signing up children to go to school without school fees. 

They
also provided school uniforms, books, t and some food to most
vulnerable children. The cost would be paid for a by a family far
away and it was called sponsorship. Maybe, just maybe this was true
and someone did care about children like you maybe there was more to
life; maybe there would be a chance, an open door to have hope.
Maybe, someone did care. 
The reality is that you and I can
make the difference in the lives of children in Kikandwa. You can go
there like I and many others have done and actually work amongst
them, or you can contribute your money to an agency that will do so
on your behalf.
There
is a catch however.
Often
only a small portion can reach the child who really needs the help,
so one has to ask questions, such as how much of your money goes to
actually supporting your child? How much of it is used in
administration, fundraising and so on, goes toward the child and its
development in Uganda. which is why this campaign is so important to us 




Meet
Namukuye Nooren


Noreen
is now around 5 years old. She lives in Uganda in a Village called
Kasejjere. Noreen doesn't stay with her parents as her father passed
away in a car accident and her mother was a prostitute in the village
and passed away recently.
One
day Noreen elderly sister heard that there was free education at a
local school and so she came along to see if she could apply. 200
other children turned up with their parents or guardians but there
were only 30 places. Noreen’s sister like many others was turned
down.
However
she was not going to give up, so she came back each day hoping that
she would be accepted. For two weeks she kept coming back to the
school and each day she would be sent home.
I
was at that school and watched as children stood for hours hoping
that they would receive something as basic as an education. I was
amazed at how many turned up looking for something which we take so
much for granted.
That
was when I decided that I should do something, and KEA was birthed. I
said that I would get sponsors for five children.
I
would go home and tell the people here that we need to do something.
The
next day five children turned up to the school hoping to be accepted
but expecting to get sent away.
This
time they didn't get sent home. Today they would start school.
That
was when I met John Kaganga. Noreen has now been attending school for
two years and she hopes that someday she will look after her
Grandmother and get a job where she doesn't have to be a prostitute.



KEA
now sponsors well over 15 children and supports each year. Here are
just some of those children: Through the support of many generous
people, and the hard work of numerous young people in schools,
churches and youth groups, KEA has raised over US$ 5000 in the past
ten years to help build temporary buildings, and support many
children in need. Any donations we received will be put to excellent use helping this wonderful dynamic hard working community .

story:
Help us continue our Co-operative

We are a group of teachers and staff from Ateneo de Zamboanga University who operates a small food business in the school. We are raising funds to open a new area and help more of our members help their families through micro-finance and credit.  

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are raising funds to improve and open a better food service for our students.
  • We want to hire a nutritionist to monitor health standards in serving food and maintain a healthier environment for the children.
  • We want to offer affordable service and generate sufficient income for our members. 
The funds that we raise shall:
  • Help build a social venture among teachers as a response to equality and micro entrepreneurship.
  • Encourage more members to volunteer and practice leadership for the welfare and sustainability of the cooperative and the good of the entire community.
  • Create additional services and resources (better food counters, kitchen utensils, equipment) to better serve the community.

Risks & Challenges

Peace and order is always tested in the peninsula with the continuing threats of conflict and peace efforts between government and the revolutionary groups in Mindanao. The city is frequently in the midst of heightened alerts. Business operations become uncertain but the community learns to adapt and be resilient. The small venture of this group enables additional savings in the midst of the calamities or misfortunes caused by nature or man. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • We would appreciate any help we can get. Your involvement, big or small, shall mean a lifeline to the people we share our services and resources.
  • Please also introduce us to your generous friends who would like to help fellow teachers in our community.

God bless you.

story:
Thank you for taking the time to check out my campaign and helping me be free of my student debt. 

Current Community Service
Through AmeriCorps, I'm teaching music at Fossil Elementary School in Fossil, Oregon to K-8th grade students. Due to budget cuts, many schools have removed their music programs. The Rural Music Outreach Program (organized by Ethos Music Center in Portland, OR) places members such as myself in schools throughout rural Oregon to teach in the classroom and instruct private lessons. 

Debt
The breakdown of my debt is as follows:
University Accounting Service - $3,000
Private Personal Loan - $13,584.52
Great Lakes Borrowers - $32,000. 15
Total - $48,584.67
I've already paid back $3,606.02 since graduating in June 2014, making monthly payments of $535.57. 

Why donate to me? 
I believe I'm worthy of your generosity because I want to devote my life entirely to the service of others. Teaching music has shown me the positive impact music can have in a person's life. I want to share that happiness with as many people as possible. 
Jobs with the purpose of community service do not provide a lot of money. That means that in order to pay back my loans, I'd have to get a job whose focus is elsewhere. I want to my focus my entire existence to the service of others. 

Extra Money Received
Any extra money I receive through this campaign with be donated to the charity Foster Care to Success. A disproportionate amount of my students are in the foster care system, and it's been hard on my heart to see the lack of unconditional love they experience. This charity provides scholarships and other resources to students in the foster care system to pursue a college education so that they may one day support a family and show their children the unconditional love the missed during their upbringing. 

Music
For one of the perks, I'm offering to write music per your request. To get an idea of the style of music I enjoy writing, check out my SoundCloud page.

story:
About Camp Hapitok

Camp Hapitok was founded in 1970 and serves children with speech/language disorders in San Luis Obispo County. Each camper is hand selected by their local Speech/Language Pathologist, and then paired 1:1 with a specially trained teen volunteer for 4 weeks of summer camp. During camp, the teen volunteers and campers do everything thing together - but the teen volunteer is always focused on their campers speech/language goals. Campers get 30 minutes of intensive small group speech therapy each day, and the teen volunteer (TIGR) is trained to provide constant support, prompting and reinforcing of their individual campers speech/language goals. Camp Hapitok runs one 4-week session, and during that 4 weeks most campers meet or exceed their Annual IEP goals for the targets they are working on.

Heading into our 45th year, our partnership with our lead sponsor - the County Office of Education - has changed, and we are in need of YOUR help to #SaveCampHapitok


What We Need & What You Get

In order to hold Camp Hapitok 2015 - our 45th year - we need to raise at least $55,000. These funds will cover staff costs, food, transportation, supplies, field trips, camp shirts, small incentives and leave us with a small amount of seed money for Hapitok 2016!!

When you donate to Camp Hapitok, you are actively participating in making a difference in 56 lives this summer- 28 elementary students with special needs, and 28 teenagers who are volunteering their summers.

When you make a donation - you could also receive:
A purple bracelet
A handwritten postcard from a Camper, TIGR or Staff Member
An awesome purple t-shirt (purple is our camp color)
Your very own camp name and name-tag
and more!


The Impact

Students involved in Camp Hapitok are impacted for a lifetime.  Ryan is a Princeton student and former camper whose life was changed after attending the camp as a sixth grader.  After a challenging 6th grade year, where he struggled with his speech/language disorder, the skills he gained at Camp Hapitok gave him a new-found confidence.  He blossomed in middle school and high school, eventually returning to Camp Hapitok as an outstanding TIGR and later a staff member.  Ryan is currently attending Princeton University on a full scholarship, and credits Camp Hapitok as a springboard to his success.


Risks & Challenges

In late January, our partnership with our primary partner, the San Luis County Office of Education, changed. We found out that we can no longer exist in an operator/employer partnership, and we need to become an independent organization. This, while best for Hapitok in the long term, has created a fiscal crisis in the present. 

In a very short amount of time we need to:
  • Raise at least 55K to hold Camp 2015
  • Find an independent agency to provide HR and Payroll support
  • Define new process and procedures to make sure that we are providing the gold standard experience to our Campers, TIGRs and Staff. 
  • Determine the strategy to secure 150K for Camp Hapitok 2016 and beyond


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share our story!
  • Use the Indiegogo Share tools to get the word out!

#SaveCampHapitok

#SaveCampHapitok

story:
I was seventeen in June 2011 when I was promised the world by an American basketball scout hunting for talent in Nigeria. He was told that I would travel to the United States to play ball and to attend high school with the hope of continuing to university on an athletic scholarship.

Through an elaborate scheme of perhaps well-meaning actors, I was trafficked to the U.S. to play basketball in Mississippi. I was exploited so that my AAU coaches – by gambling on my future – could earn money and prestige. I was subjected to slave-like conditions in Mississippi where I was not fed and was forced to sleep on the floor while playing basketball or working out for the majority of each day. I fled and less than two years after arriving in the U.S. to fulfill my dreams, I was homeless and undocumented in New York City.

I knew that what had occurred to me and to other foreign-born student athletes was not right and possibly illegal. I sought the assistance of African Services Committee, a non-profit Harlem-based organization, to remedy my situation. Within a few months, I legalized my immigration status.

Now, I work as a security guard and am attempting to save money to finance my education. I dream of studying sound engineering. I need help to reach my goal.

For more information on me, please the WNYC story featuring me (http://tinyurl.com/q6qtesl), as well as the Harper’s Magazine April edition.

story:
Who Am I and Why am I raising money

My name is Duron Chavis; I am an urban farmer and community activist from Richmond Virginia. I am project director for the Harding Street Urban Ag Center in Petersburg Virginia and community engagement director for Renew Richmond a hyperlocal nonprofit that uses urban agriculture to address poverty and food insecuity. I need your help promoting indoor farming as a vehicle to do that and to  teach STEM in Richmond Public Schools.


Investing in students of Richmond Public Schools is a passion of mine. Several years ago, I partnered with Capital One to install school gardens in George Wythe High School and through Renew Richmond we have installed a one acre farm at Armstrong High School. Our desire has been to help students eat healthier while connecting them to job and entrepreneurship opportunities in the local food system in ways that address issues of food access in the Southside and the East End of Richmond VA.



Indoor vertical farming conserves water and can produce more food in less space than traditional outdoor farming. We want to introduce vertical aeroponic farming to students while also giving them the opportunity to grow food all year round to address food insecurity in their respective communities. The Tower Garden serves as an excellent vehicle to do that while also teaching STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math). We have developed an associated curriculum that teaches critical thinking, food systems and that addresses a number of components of the Next Generation Science Standards.


We need YOUR help!! You can help Renew Richmond address both food insecurity and poverty through the provision of classroom infrastructure that will engage students through STEM education to solve real world problems. Please support Duron Chavis and Renew Richmond in their efforts to teach students how to farm for the future!

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need Tower Gardens: We aren't looking to pay staff or marketing or anything like that. We just need funding to purchase Tower Gardens for the schools. Our organization already has staff in schools teaching urban gardening and culinary arts. Your investment will allow us to take this effort to the next level through indoor farming.
  • We have super fresh swag: We have amazing perks in the form of t-shirts, tote bags, chef aprons, your name on a tower garden - all to recognize your contribution to this project and to remind you of how you made a difference with your dollars with Renew Richmond


  • Our goal is to get 20 towers - 10 for George Wythe High School and 10 for Armstrong High School. If we don't get all the funds - we will get as many towers as we can and distribute them evenly between both schools.


The Impact

How will this project impact students in Richmond Public Schools?

  • Indoor Classroom Farm: We will teach students hands-on about food from seed to harvest, and will connect lessons to classroom curriculum
  • Healthier Students: Students who grow their own food have higher likelihood of eating what they grow! (Center for Disease Control) You can help students from food insecure neighborhoods get fresh locally grown veggies in their bellies through investing in our project.
  • Real World STEM application: Today, STEM means creating learning environments that allow students to be more active. Whenever that happens, students are engaged in their own learning. There’s no manipulation in getting students active, either, it just happens. The outcome is that students better remember what they’ve learned when they are engaged in the process, and not passive by-standers. They are also learning how to apply STEM to real world problems that they experience in their community on a daily basis specifically in the context of food deserts and food insecurity.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute to our project there are other ways you can help:

  • Promote, promote promote! Tell your friends, tell your church, tell your civic organization, tell your fraternity or sorority, tell the news media, tell your favorite blogger, tell your local philantropist friends, tell any and everybody about what we are doing so that we can make this a reality.
  • Lets Sit Down and Talk About it: Organize a dinner and let us come talk about it! If you can't contribute; get several of your friends and family together and let us come and explain what we are doing and why it is important!

100% of the tax-deductible funds raised in this campaign will be used toward the purchase of equipment
